HEADLINE: Japan and China Dispute a Pacific Islet

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 9 

 BODY:
The smaller of the two is roughly the size of a twin bed and pokes only 2.9 inches out of the ocean. The larger, as big as a small bedroom perhaps, manages to rise up 6.3 inches. 
 The Japanese government has already spent $600 million to keep the two barren islets in the western Pacific above water. Collectively called Okinotori and located 1,082 miles south of here, the islets have long allowed Tokyo to claim exclusive economic control over an ocean area larger than all of Japan. 
 But a threat potentially bigger than typhoons or global warming emerged last year when China challenged Japan's exclusive rights to the economically and militarily important waters, describing Okinotori as just a ''rock.'' 
 Rock or island, Okinotori lies in a three-square-mile coral reef, most of which is under water even at low tide. A few decades ago, the area was dotted with half a dozen islets, but by 1989, only two were still visible. To protect its claim, the government in Tokyo encased the tiny protrusions -- some 1,400 yards apart -- in 82-foot-thick concrete, an effort that cost $280 million. Workers later covered the smaller islet with a $50 million titanium net to shield it from debris thrown up by the waves.
 Finally, slits were made across the concrete casing, so it would comply with the United Nations law that an island be ''surrounded by water.''
 As with some of Japan's other territorial disputes, a patriotic organization with right-wing roots has taken the lead in rebutting the Chinese challenge to Okinotori's status. The organization, the Nippon Foundation, has drawn short-term plans to build a lighthouse and long-term ones to increase the size of the islets by breeding micro-organisms known as foraminifera. The government last month installed a radar, repaired a heliport and placed an official address plaque, ''1 Okinotori Island, Ogasawara Village, Tokyo.'' 
 Shintaro Ishihara, the tough-talking governor of Tokyo, under whose jurisdiction the islets fall, took reporters to Okinotori recently and raised the Japanese flag on it.
 ''That's an island,'' he said later. ''A tiny island. Territory.''
 ''Got a problem with that?'' he said with a grin.
 The Chinese do. In a meeting with Japanese officials last year, they said Okinotori could not be regarded as an island under the United Nations Law of the Sea.
 According to the law, an ''island is a naturally formed area of land, surrounded by water, which is above water at high tide.'' Furthermore, it adds, ''rocks which cannot sustain human habitation or economic life of their own shall have no exclusive economic zone.''
 Okinotori lies at a militarily strategic point, midway between Taiwan and Guam, where American forces are based. Chinese vessels -- whose increasing forays into this disputed exclusive economic zone have been drawing Japanese protests -- are believed to be mapping the sea bottom over which Americans warships might pass on their way to Taiwan.
 Washington supports Tokyo on the island versus rock issue. But a visit to Tokyo in February by John R. Bolton, then an under secretary of state, no doubt left the Japanese scratching their heads: With friends like these, who needs the Chinese?
 An American reporter unable to pronounce Okinotori shima, which means ''Offshore bird island,'' asked Mr. Bolton about ''Otokono shima,'' a nonexistent island that would mean, ''Man's island.''
 ''The rock,'' Mr. Bolton said.
 ''Yeah, the rock,'' the reporter said.
 No one has ever lived on Okinotori, and the islets have yet to show any sign of economic life. Workers are deployed twice a year to make repairs to the casing that sits atop Okinotori, and this year, after China's ''rock'' declaration, the Ministry of Land raised the budget for it to $5.6 million, from $2 million. 
 Last fall, fearing that inaction would mean losing out to China, the Nippon Foundation focused its considerable resources on the issue. 
 ''If someone doesn't do it, this country would drag its feet and nothing would be decided,'' said Yoshihiko Yamada, who oversees the Okinotori project for the foundation.
 The foundation led teams of researchers and reporters on two boat trips to Okinotori. Mr. Yamada, something of a romantic, waxed poetic about the ''moonlit sea,'' the ''mysterious natural environment'' and the flyingfish jumping merrily around the ship.
 ''We made it into sashimi and it was delicious,'' he said.
 The foundation now wants to build a $1 million lighthouse, which would constitute economic activity by guiding ships. ''If the government can't do that, we are asking them to let us do it,'' Mr. Yamada said. 
 Other proposals include opening up Okinotori to divers or ecotourists. Masazumi Nagamitsu, an executive director at the foundation, is partial to an international coral research center and a 6,500-foot runway. An even more ambitious proposal would reverse the land erosion by attracting foraminifera -- hard-shelled organisms that would attach themselves to the islet. 
 ''Well, I wonder what their intention is with these proposals,'' said Katsunori Kadoyu, an official at the Ministry of Land, which administers Okinotori. He has yet to step foot on Okinotori but watches live images of it from a camera set up there in February. ''It is a bit difficult to answer.''
 Part of the difficulty lies in the history of the Nippon Foundation, which was founded by Ryoichi Sasakawa, a World War II war-crimes suspect who built a gambling empire around motorboat racing.
 Yukio Hori, a retired professor at Tohoku Bunka Gakuen University and author, said the government and nationalist groups often had a collaborative relationship. Those groups would typically push a project that government officials were hesitant to do openly. 
 In another territorial dispute with China, over the Senkaku Islands, Japan's largest right-wing group, Nihon Seinen-sha, built a lighthouse there 27 years ago and traveled to it regularly for repairs. After the government and Nihon Seinen-sha engaged in negotiations last year, the government finally took over control of the lighthouse early this year.
 On Okinotori, the government may let the foundation build its lighthouse. Doing so on its own could be too provocative to the Chinese.
 ''In some aspect,'' Mr. Nagamitsu said, ''we are doing things that the government finds a bit difficult to do, or that they are entrusting us to do, or hoping we would do.''

HEADLINE: The Market's Up. Why Do We Feel Blue?

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM

 BODY:
THE second quarter proved to be, well, a conundrum for mutual fund investors.
 On paper, the quarter was rather successful. The average domestic stock fund, for example, advanced 2.8 percent, reversing a slide of 2.3 percent in the first quarter. Among general domestic stock funds, the gain for the quarter was 2.4 percent.
The gains were fairly widespread. Money was made in small-company and blue-chip stock funds -- and in growth-oriented and value-oriented portfolios. And both stock and bond funds posted solid gains, on average, in contrast to the first quarter, when both lost ground. Stock and bond funds benefited from an unexpected fall in long-term interest rates, which Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, called a ''conundrum.'' 
 And some of the big winners -- again -- were real estate sector funds, which soared 13 percent, on average, in the quarter; utilities funds, up 7.5 percent; and natural resources funds, up 2.4 percent, as crude oil futures prices hit $60 a barrel in the quarter.
 Yet investors emerged from the second quarter less optimistic than they were at the start of the year, when many stock and bond funds were in the red.
 Despite a slight improvement in June, the UBS Index of Investor Optimism remains substantially below its level in the first quarter. That may explain why net new cash flows into stock funds were down 38 percent this year through May, versus the corresponding period last year, according to the Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund industry trade group.
 ''I'm shocked at the level of apathy -- perhaps even pessimism -- about the market, given the current environment for stocks,'' said Jonathan Golub, a United States equity strategist at J.P. Morgan Funds. ''The public has this thing really, really wrong.''
 Part of the public's dour mood may be attributable to the perceived gap between the performance of the equity markets and real estate. While the average sales price of an existing single-family home shot up nearly 13 percent in the 12 months through May, the stock market ''is stuck in a trading range,'' said Robert Doll, chief investment officer for Merrill Lynch Investment Managers. 
 But the real culprit may be the unpredictability of the markets themselves. ''This was one of those quarters where no one was 100 percent prescient,'' said Andrew Clark, senior research analyst at Lipper, the fund tracker.
 For instance, despite all the uncertainties surrounding inflation and oil prices, three things seemed rather certain at the start of the quarter. 
 For one, large-capitalization stocks were supposed to wrest control of the market from small-company shares, as often happens when stock market rallies mature.
 Yet that didn't necessarily happen this spring. While large-cap growth stock funds posted solid gains of 2.8 percent, small-cap growth funds did even better, climbing 4.1 percent on average, according to Morningstar. Among value-oriented funds, those that focus on large stocks advanced 1.3 percent while small-company funds surged 3 percent. 
 Heading into the third quarter, mutual fund managers and market strategists were again predicting large-cap outperformance. 
 Another assumption entering the quarter was that international stock funds were supposed to beat domestic portfolios, as the dollar was expected to weaken against the euro. But political uncertainties in Europe, caused in part by the rejection of the European constitution by French and Dutch voters, strengthened the dollar. In fact, the dollar gained 7 percent against the euro in the quarter and 11 percent in the first half of the year. 
 The dollar's unexpected climb reduced the value of foreign holdings by domestic fund investors. The average European stock fund, for example, fell 0.5 percent in the quarter, though international stock funds over all still managed gains of nearly 0.4 percent. 
 ''The dollar rallied when it wasn't supposed to,'' said Russel Kinnel, Morningstar's director of mutual fund research. ''That was a bit of a surprise.''
 An even bigger surprise, he added, was that ''bonds rallied when they weren't supposed to.''
 Heading into the quarter, one of Wall Street's biggest assumptions was that stocks would beat bonds. Long-term interest rates were expected to climb, reducing the underlying value of older bonds in fixed-income mutual funds and giving equities an advantage.
 But despite two additional increases in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board in the second quarter, yields on 10-year Treasury securities actually fell, to 3.94 percent at the end of June from 4.50 percent at the end of March. (Since the quarter ended, those yields have moved back up to around 4 percent.)
 As a result, the average taxable bond fund gained 2.1 percent in the quarter and was up 6.6 percent over the 12 months through June. Long-term government bond funds also did well, returning 5.8 percent in the quarter. That brought their 12-month gains to 14 percent. 
 So much for the end of the bull market in bonds. A growing number of market analysts say investors could be in store for a sustained period of historically low long-term interest rates.
 Consider William H. Gross, managing director of Pimco, the asset management firm based in Newport Beach, Calif. While Mr. Gross, who manages the Pimco Total Return bond fund, says it's a ''slam dunk'' that the Fed will increase short-term rates at least once more in the next few months, he thinks that 10-year Treasury yields will remain stuck in the 3 percent to 4 percent range for the next few years.
 The domestic economy is slowing, and Mr. Gross says he thinks the federal government has exhausted the traditional tools to fuel faster growth, such as further tax cuts. 
 The global appetite for Treasury securities, meanwhile, especially from China and other Asian nations, continues to grow, he said. ''There's a new bully on the block and that's the Asian buyer of Treasuries,'' Mr. Gross said. ''Unless you can get on the right side of the bully, you're going to get beaten up.''
 Because of his forecast for low-but-stable long-term rates, Mr. Gross is now recommending a strategy that few thought safe at the start of the year. He says bond investors should gravitate toward longer-maturity bonds as opposed to short-term issues, which are typically regarded as safer plays in an environment of rising rates.
 ''It's a new reality,'' Mr. Gross said. ''Under these circumstances, a bond holder should be thinking about being long duration as opposed to having a shorter duration.'' 
 As for the broad investment landscape, he says he believes investors should brace themselves for a sustained period of modest, if not mediocre, gains in both the stock and bond markets, with total returns in the mid-single digits.
 Is there anything on the horizon that could shake the markets out of their doldrums in the second half of the year?
 Mr. Doll of Merrill Lynch said the equity markets were likely to vacillate until investors had a clearer sense of when the Fed might stop tightening monetary policy. ''All eyes are on the Fed,'' he said, ''and how far they are going to go and how long it's going to take them to get there.'' 
 He says he believes that the Fed will probably stop once the federal funds rate, which banks charge one another on overnight loans, rises to 3.5 percent. That would imply just one more rate increase, since that target rate is now at 3.25 percent. But others still believe the Fed will continue raising rates to 4 percent, or higher. 
 Whatever level the rate reaches, conventional wisdom says that when the Fed stops tightening, a rally could ensue in the stock markets, maybe one that is similar to the year-end rallies of 2003 and 2004.
 But history shows that periods immediately after the end of Fed rate increases aren't always rosy. Although stocks went on a tear after the Fed stopped raising rates in 1989 and 1995, equities have more typically lost ground during such times. Ned Davis Research studied Fed tightening cycles back to 1920 and found that the Dow Jones industrial average was down 4.9 percent, on average, six months after the Fed stopped raising rates. A full year after the end of rate increases, stocks were typically down 3.9 percent.
 If history plays out, investors face ample risks well into 2006.

HEADLINE: It Didn't Start on 9/11

BYLINE: By ERIC LICHTBLAU. 
Eric Lichtblau covers the Justice Department and terrorism issues for The Times.

 BODY:

BLIND SPOT
The Secret History
of American Counterterrorism.
By Timothy Naftali.
399 pp. Basic Books. $26.

PREVENTING SURPRISE ATTACKS
Intelligence Reform
in the Wake of 9/11.
By Richard A. Posner.
214 pp. Hoover Institution/
Rowman & Littlefield Publishers. $18.95.
 THE notion that Sept. 11 changed everything has become deeply ingrained in the American psyche. Indeed, when Steven Brill gave his 2003 book on post-9/11 America a single-word title -- After'' -- everyone knew instantly what he meant. 
 Still, the idea of a pre- and post-9/11 obscures a grim reality: many of the quandaries now confronting the United States -- how to identify and defeat terrorists, how to protect the nation's borders and reduce its vulnerabilities, how to preserve our freedoms while ensuring our safety -- had been debated for decades at lower decibels. The problem is that few were paying much attention.
 Two new books, ''Blind Spot: The Secret History of American Counterterrorism,'' by Timothy Naftali, and ''Preventing Surprise Attacks: Intelligence Reform in the Wake of 9/11,'' by Richard A. Posner, remind us of something we are always told: those who forget history are doomed to repeat it. With widely differing results, both authors seek to draw lessons for the future from the long history of anti-American terrorism. 
 Naftali, an associate professor at the Miller Center of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia, demonstrates that terrorists have been a constant and menacing threat throughout much of America's recent past -- from Puerto Rican independence seekers in the 1950's to Cuban hijackers in the 1960's to Middle Eastern militants in the 1970's and beyond. But policy makers were often indifferent to these threats, or ineffective in confronting them. The occasional hijacking or the sporadic burst of violence was seen as an accepted price of governing in the modern era. Speaking of the massacre of the Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics and other atrocities, Naftali writes that terrorism was ''the annoying little gnat that buzzed around the superpower while it was trying to handle truly dangerous matters.''
 He devotes only a small chapter to the 9/11 attacks themselves -- and it will seem cursory to anyone who has read the 9/11 commission report. (This book, in fact, grew out of research and interviews that Naftali did for the commission on the history of early counterterrorism.) The real punch of ''Blind Spot'' comes in Naftali's descriptions of the advances, retreats and inertia of presidential administrations and counterterrorism officials since World War II. And in an understated style, he points out the haunting similarities between the events surrounding 9/11 and the attacks and policy debates from previous generations. 
 There was, for instance, the Sunday in September 1970 when Palestinian terrorists attempted the simultaneous hijacking of four airliners flying from Europe to New York. All the hostages were eventually released, but it was ''a feat not replicated by a terrorist organization until September 2001,'' Naftali writes.
 There were the constant and often unresolved debates beginning in the 1970's over issues that ring familiar today: whether American officials should seek merely to gather intelligence on terrorists or engage in more aggressive law enforcement and military activities to prevent attacks; whether officials should negotiate with terrorists or simply confront them; whether the government should force airlines to upgrade security at the expense of passenger convenience and profit margins; and even whether certain militant groups should be defined as terrorists in the first place.
 There was the warning in 1976 by Ronald Reagan, then a presidential candidate, about the danger of allowing civil-rights-minded ''bleeding hearts'' to dismantle intelligence operations against domestic terrorists, a warning that foreshadowed similar statements a quarter-century later by George W. Bush and his first attorney general, John Ashcroft. 
 There was the ambitious attempt by the Reagan administration in 1984, following the bombing of the Marine barracks in Beirut and other attacks, to launch a comprehensive assault that would constitute ''taking the fight to the terrorists.'' But four proposed antiterrorism measures got bogged down in Congress, and the C.I.A. resisted structural changes.
 And long before the Bush administration's efforts to link Saddam Hussein to Al Qaeda, the Reagan White House, looking through a cold-war-era lens, attempted to place much of the blame for terrorism on the Soviet Union.
 For most of the three decades before 9/11, Naftali writes, American officials failed to treat terrorism as a strategic threat. But ''it is a tactic that will be used again and again,'' and, he concludes, it is essential that we maintain ''a long-term capability to deal with terrorism at home as well as abroad.''
 Like ''Blind Spot,'' Richard Posner's ''Preventing Surprise Attacks'' grew out of the 9/11 commission. A federal judge in Chicago, a law professor and a prolific author, Posner wrote an extensive analysis of the commission report for The New York Times Book Review last August. That piece -- generally critical of the commission's work -- forms the basis of this book.
 Unfortunately, Posner largely mimics his earlier analysis, adding little beyond heft. His central thesis is that some terrorist attacks, 9/11 among them, may simply be unpreventable and that the commission's rush to fix the system through what Posner sees as an overly centralized intelligence apparatus appears misguided, perhaps even counterproductive. Despite the public reaction after 9/11, he writes, ''our intelligence system may not be broken after all.'' 
 Like Naftali, Posner examines past attacks to draw lessons for future policy. But oddly, the three episodes he treats in the greatest depth as examples of successful surprise attacks -- Pearl Harbor, the Tet offensive in Vietnam and the 1973 Yom Kippur attacks on Israel by Egypt and Syria -- were all military operations that do not fit the conventional definition of terrorism. They were carried out by foreign nations, not rogue groups like Al Qaeda or Hamas.
 Posner uses these episodes as the basis for an often impenetrable section full of formulas for anticipating and deterring terrorist attacks, with variables like the probability of an attack, the potential damage, economic cost and the public reaction. In fairness, he opens the section by advising that ''the mathless reader can read around it.'' But even the mathematically inclined may have difficulty wading through calculations like S = pa(d) + c(d) + (1 / p)w(p, d).
 IN the end, Posner settles into a simpler explanation: while surprise terrorist attacks may be deterred, and their impact blunted by measures like the stocking of vaccines to guard against bioterror attacks, they cannot be reliably prevented. 
 ''Preventing Surprise Attacks'' provides an at-times useful and contrarian view of the commission report. But by his own admission, Posner offers no real blueprint for how he thinks America's counterterrorism program could be improved. And in a book that lacks the taut writing or drama of the 9/11 report he is criticizing, he too often veers into diatribe. He attacks the politics, backgrounds, recommendations and even the unanimity of the 9/11 commissioners, and he challenges the expertise of victims' family members in influencing commission policy, calling their role in the process ''amateurism run wild.''
 Those without the time or mathematical proclivity are probably better advised to read the truncated version of the book he wrote for these pages last year. Better yet, if they haven't already done so, they might read the 9/11 report on which it is based.

HEADLINE: Freebooters of Industry

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LIND. 
Michael Lind is the Whitehead senior fellow at the New America Foundation in Washington.

 BODY:

HOT PROPERTY
The Stealing of Ideas
in an Age of Globalization.
By Pat Choate.
352 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.
 IN recent years a series of reports have provided evidence about the erosion of America's scientific and industrial base. But ''strikingly,'' as Pat Choate observes in ''Hot Property: The Stealing of Ideas in an Age of Globalization,'' ''the massive theft of U.S.-owned intellectual properties as a contributing cause to America's technological decline has been almost totally overlooked in these reports.'' In this timely and important book, Choate sounds the alarm about the threat posed by such piracy.
 Choate, who is best known as Ross Perot's vice-presidential candidate in 1996, has sounded alarms before. When he published ''Agents of Influence,'' his study of Washington lobbyists funded by the Japanese government and Japanese corporations, he was denounced as a Japan-basher. Today the assertion that Japan has practiced result-oriented mercantilism rather than free trade for decades is rarely disputed. When Choate, like Perot, warned that as a result of the North American Free Trade Agreement, American corporations would move their factories to Mexico to take advantage of low labor costs, he was portrayed as a Mexico-basher. Bill Clinton and Al Gore argued that Mexico would be a market for American manufactured goods. Instead, according to the economist Charles McMillion: ''The large U.S. net export losses to Mexico since Nafta are concentrated in autos, machinery, electronics, apparel and furniture. U.S. net export gains are largely in agribusiness and bulk commodities such as cereals and organic chemicals.'' Score two out of two for Choate.
 In his latest campaign, Choate is likely to find allies in the business community -- and opponents among some champions of developing nations, as well as some libertarians who argue for weakening or eliminating intellectual property rights. Choate quotes the definition of ''copyright industries'' used by the International Intellectual Property Alliance: ''music and book publishing, radio and television broadcasting, cable television, newspapers and periodicals, records and tapes, motion pictures, theatrical productions, advertising, computer software and data processing'' -- to which others, like pharmaceuticals, can be added. According to the intellectual property alliance, ''worldwide digital piracy costs America's copyright industry $20 billion to $22 billion annually, and that approximation excludes illegal Internet downloads.'' 
 Patents, copyrights, trademarks and other intellectual property rights are useless if governments do not enforce them against thieves. However, officials in many developing nations are more concerned about promoting national economic growth by disseminating know-how than with protecting the rights of foreigners. Choate tells the story of Haima, a Chinese corporation that is the largest woven-carpet manufacturer in Asia. After Milliken & Company, the largest private textile company in the United States, lost a Chinese contract to Haima, ''Milliken personnel obtained a copy of Haima's 1999 carpet catalog. It featured 16 copyrighted Milliken designs.'' Although an American court ordered Haima to pay Milliken more than $4 million, the American company has been unable to collect.
 Choate acknowledges that as an industrializing nation in the 19th century the United States engaged in many of the practices that it condemns today, including industrial espionage. He recounts the tales of Samuel Slater, who brought secret British spinning machine technology to the United States, and Francis Cabot Lowell, a Boston patrician who used his photographic memory to steal the trade secrets of British textile manufacturers. ''The most important feature of the Patent Act of 1793,'' Choate writes, ''was what it did not provide: protections for foreign inventors. Only American citizens were eligible for a U.S. patent. Thus, any American could bring a foreign innovation to the United States and commercialize the idea, all with total legal immunity.'' In later generations, Germany and Japan similarly manipulated intellectual property rights.
 In the 1990's, concern about the theft of intellectual property inspired the United States to promote the Trade Related Intellectual Property System. ''Ironically,'' Choate observes, ''after leading the long, historic fight to put these global protections into place, Washington is now strangely unwilling to use them.'' He notes that ''since June 2000, the U.S. has not filed a single intellectual property case at the World Trade Organization.''
 Choate contrasts the attention that the Clinton administration paid to these issues with the lack of interest the Bush administration has displayed. The difference may be one of constituencies. ''Copyright industries'' like the movie and technology sectors provide much of the financial support for the Democratic Party, and they are far more threatened by intellectual property violations than are the commodity producers of the Republican red states. This interpretation finds support in Choate's data on the World Trade Organization: ''Overall, the Bush administration filed only 12 cases with the W.T.O. during its first four years in office. Six of those dealt with foreign impediments to U.S. agricultural exports -- beef, rice, genetically enhanced foods, corn, wheat, cheeses, dairy products and apples.'' 
 Choate says that while industrializing countries may benefit from piracy, the world as a whole loses. ''Piracy and counterfeiting impede innovation: thieves do not invest in research, design, production, development or advertising. . . . The result is fewer new medicines, fewer advances in science, fewer new products, fewer new music CD's, fewer new movies, less new software and higher prices for whatever is created.'' Everyone is harmed, either directly or indirectly, ''when thieves steal from Microsoft and Disney.'' And, he concludes, ''What is missing is the will of U.S. political leaders to confront those who are stealing U.S.-owned intellectual properties and with them the future of the American people.''

HEADLINE: Customizing the Cookie Cutter

BYLINE: By DEBRA MORGENSTERN KATZ

 BODY:
ACROSS Long Island, the post-World War II split-level houses, the ranches and the development colonials, each looking just like the neighbor's, are undergoing makeovers that are changing the look of the Island's tract house developments. 
 In previous generations, a family that needed more space would add a room that matched the existing house. Today, homeowners often change the exterior to give it a new architectural stamp, but frequently with design elements from earlier eras.
 ''They're looking for older details that went away in the postwar development of Long Island,'' said Jim Smiros, an architect with Smiros & Smiros in Glen Cove. ''They're trying to bring some of that character back to their homes.''
 Brenda and Glenn Cummins of Rockville Centre decided they needed a bigger kitchen and more bedrooms in their 41-year-old two-story high ranch because they have four children. They also knew that the windows did not work well and that the siding was old, so they did not stop at the interior work. They completely redesigned the exterior so there is no longer any sign of a high ranch; the house looks more like a Dutch colonial. 
 ''My parents thought we were nuts,'' said Ms. Cummins, whose family moved out of the house for three months last year while it was renovated.
 The Cumminses' architect, Bruce Spenadel, who is based in Great Neck, said at least 90 percent of his residential projects now include redesigning the exterior; that percentage has doubled in the last decade. Other architects said more than 80 percent of their clients now want to make the outside of their houses look more individual. 
 An important-looking front entry is the No.1 detail that homeowners ask for, Mr. Spenadel said. Porches and gabled roof lines are popular requests, as are natural materials like cedar shingles, copper gutters and wood crown moldings. 
 Plenty of renovation is going on. Although towns do not keep separate statistics on exterior design changes, more-general statistics show there have been significant increases in home remodeling in recent years. 
 In Nassau County, the number of residential remodeling permits issued over the last four years increased by about 30 percent. In the Town of Hempstead, remodeling permits jumped to 4,029 last year from 3,027 in 2000. In North Hempstead, 470 permits were issued in 2000 and 604 last year. In Oyster Bay, 1,339 permits were granted in 2000 and 1,796 last year. 
 Kate Murray, the supervisor for the Town of Hempstead, said permit requests have increased so much that revenues from the permit fees have been ''off the charts.'' 
 In Hempstead, the remodeling permits -- which typically cost $100 for the first $1,000 of construction plus $12 for each additional $1,000 -- brought in almost $2 million for the town last year. 
 ''It's been sort of an explosion in our building department,'' she said.
 In Suffolk County, the Town of Islip reported a 62 percent increase in remodeling permits, to 1,620 last year from 999 in 2000. The Town of Huntington had its biggest year ever in 2003, with 966 permits granted compared with 773 in 2001. It had a drop last year to 796, but town officials said permits issued this year were running ahead of last year. The Town of Brookhaven issued 4,895 permits last year, compared with 3,520 in 2001. 
 Architects cited several reasons for the increases. 
 ''The housing stock on Long Island is at an age when it needs renovation,'' said Mr. Smiros, the Glen Cove architect. ''While they're at it, people have decided they might as well personalize it.''
 Mr. Spenadel said the continuing rise in house prices was making moving up difficult and remodeling more attractive. ''My clients are saying, 'I looked around, I really wanted to make the jump to the next level home, but I just can't swing it,''' he said. Instead, they are turning their house into their dream home.
 The idea to redesign the exterior sometimes comes at the architect's suggestion. Mr. Spenadel showed the Cumminses several possibilities. 
 ''I had no idea what I wanted,'' Ms. Cummins said. The final design includes a gambrel roof, which has two slopes on each side, the lower slope steeper than the upper. ''My kids call it a farmhouse,'' she said. ''I like it because there are not that many houses around here with that kind of roofline.'' 
 Sometimes the idea comes from the homeowners. For Bob and Maryanne Pedersen, it began with siding that needed to be replaced, but then ''it just kind of snowballed,'' said Mrs. Pedersen, who lives next door to the Cumminses in Rockville Centre. The Pedersens hired the same architect, Mr. Spenadel, but were not looking to expand. They wanted to create ''a nice presentation'' on the outside, Mrs. Pedersen said. 
 ''We wanted to give the house a feeling of more substance,'' she said.
 Mr. Pedersen searched online for exterior redesigns for split-level houses and handed the architect pictures of things they admired, like heavy white moldings and gabled rooflines.
 ''Then my husband and the architect worked for almost six, seven months, back and forth, to create what we really wanted,'' Mrs. Pedersen said. 
 The Pedersens brought out their foyer several feet to create a more dramatic entry, with six columns and an arch, and created a 20-foot-high barrel ceiling inside the foyer. Outside, they added several gables and prominent white molding and trims.
 A project that is only an exterior remodeling is not unusual anymore and has become more common in the last five years, said Harry Van Meter, a Garden City architect. An exterior remodeling may cost between $50,000 and $100,000, he said.
 ''We've had projects where the whole project was nothing more than redoing siding and changing the roofing,'' he said. ''I think people are looking for more curb appeal.'' 
 Mr. Smiros just finished redesigning the exterior of his own house in Oyster Bay, a colonial that was identical to a dozen others in his neighborhood; the new siding, windows, moldings and shutters changed it into a traditional New England Federal style.
 Rebecca and Mark Gunton of Huntington knew they needed more space after the birth of their third child, but they did not stop at a simple expansion. 
 ''We wanted to make the outside a bit more interesting, give it more character,'' she said. For her husband, she added, ''that was almost as important as the extra space.'' 
 The architect, Alex Latham of ADL III Architecture in Northport, worked with their contractor, Robert Pear of Huntington, and the original 1960's development colonial is nowhere to be found in the new exterior.
 Mr. Latham said he thought such architectural changes were good for the Long Island landscape. He said the lack of strong design that developed in post-World War II housing developments was a result of rapid low-cost mass production for returning G.I.'s and the lack of training in traditional design at architectural schools that were all stressing Modernism.
 ''They pared down the details to build houses in a very economical way,'' Mr. Latham said, leaving buyers with houses that looked the same. 
 ''I think that's a travesty,'' he said. ''It's boring, it's uncreative, it's a dumbing down of the aesthetic.'' 
 Mr. Latham said clients had become more savvy as a result of the increase in home design magazines and television shows like ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,'' which drastically renovated a St. James ranch house in March, and the HGTV series ''Curb Appeal.'' 
 ''They are much more educated and sophisticated and exposed to design,'' Mr. Latham said.
 That increasing sophistication has come with a willingness to spend. ''They definitely are spending more,'' Mr. Pear said. ''A lot of that is because construction costs themselves have risen dramatically.'' 
 It is also because with prices so high, there is more equity to pull out of a home, he said. And because the value of houses is much higher, the owners are not afraid to make costly improvements.
 The increased remodeling costs are also a result of what features homeowners are choosing. 
 ''The trend is more toward high-end desires,'' Mr. Pear said, with homeowners expecting expensive details like granite countertops in kitchens and crown moldings.
 In Nassau County, remodeling permits issued show increases per project. In Hempstead, homeowners spent nearly $59.1 million in 2000 and $135.4 million last year, with a 70 percent increase per job. In North Hempstead, estimated spending increased to $28 million last year from $16.8 million in 2000, about a 30 percent increase per project. In Oyster Bay, estimated spending increased $73.7 million last year from almost $47.6 million in 2000, about 15 percent per job. 
 Geoffrey Hoovis of Oceanside, who runs a contracting company called Built to Perfection, and his wife, Nancy, are renovating their raised ranch home, a project that began for extra space but ended up including an exterior redesign with a turret. 
 ''I wanted to do something different being that I'm in the field, something a little more elaborate,'' Mr. Hoovis said. He worked with an architect, David Massa of Port Washington. 
 Though the project is not finished, a neighbor down the block has hired Mr. Massa to put a turret on his house. Mr. Massa said he did not worry that a new sameness would develop as neighbors copy one another. 
 ''It'll be interpreted differently,'' he said. ''Because the architecture on the outside reflects what's going on inside, everyone has a different program for what they're trying to achieve.'' 

When It's Better to Just Start Over
 Geoffrey Hoovis, a contractor from Oceanside, says that when a homeowner wants very extensive renovations to a house, it may cost less - as much as 30 percent less - to knock the house down and build anew instead. 
 That strategy does create other problems, though, like where to live during construction. It also invites more restrictions and intrusions from zoning boards and building inspectors, especially in incorporated villages, said Bruce Spenadel, an architect from Great Neck. 
 Officials treat some big projects that way even if much of the old house is to remain. The Town of Hempstead uses a 50-percent rule: if the dollar amount of the remodeling exceeds half the value of the house, the project is regulated as if it were new construction. A new certificate of occupancy is required, and codes for new homes must be followed. 
 Mr. Spenadel has his own 50 percent rule: If you are significantly changing more than half the structure, think about knocking it down instead.

HEADLINE: Where the Living Is Easier

BYLINE: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

 BODY:
FROM the back balcony of their 1876 Victorian on North Street in the historic district of Litchfield, H. Sean Mathis, an investment banker, and his wife, Florence de Dampierre, an author and designer who grew up in Paris, look east across their five acres and see their pool house and greenhouse beyond a stand of grand spruces. 
 Their daughter, 7, motors by, laughing and calling out as she helps a landscaper steer a tractor across the yard.
''Next she'll want to learn to drive,'' says Mr. Mathis, sitting at an afternoon table -- French, 19th century -- where iced coffee in glass goblets and sweet and airy macaroons have been set out for friends just in for the weekend from Rye, N.Y.
 A few miles away, from the back deck of the small frame cottage on North Shore Road that he has spent three decades winterizing, Joe Lanza looks south beyond a sunlit swamp maple, away from the public boat launch and the campground, and sips white wine with a neighbor as the evening breeze ripples Bantam Lake. 
 The hot tub remains under cover, and no Jet Skis are out this Thursday evening to rile his collie, Ben. The weekenders have yet to invade.
 ''Look out there, they're huge,'' Mr. Lanza said, pointing at houses much larger than his across the lake, new homes built -- by New Yorkers, he presumes -- in place of several smaller houses on the lake's south shore. 
 Mr. Lanza came from Waterbury and owns a cottage a few miles from the center of town. Mr. Mathis and Ms. de Dampierre came from New York and own a showcase house a short walk from the green. 
 But while distance and demographics may separate them, they have fulfilled the same ambition, one that is increasingly common among those who come to Litchfield: They wanted to be here more often, not just on weekends, not just in summer, not just part time, and they have found a way to do it.
 ''Our hearts are here,'' said Ms. de Dampierre. 
 So are their fingerprints. Just as people have created new, more-invested lives for themselves here, they have created a new Litchfield. The once sleepy summer escape is now a sophisticated self-contained destination, where social and cultural options are available year round, from antiques to theater to restaurants, and where outsiders evolve into locals by sending their kids to local schools, stretching their social realms beyond their circles in the city and importing the rest of the world through the Internet.
 The town population no longer shifts significantly with the seasons. Residents with long memories say there are distinctive measures of change.
 ''One of the big jobs was turning the water off and turning the water on at all of the big houses,'' said Martin Moraghan, 89, whose father once ran a grocery store in town.
 New York City, still the economic engine that makes the new Litchfield possible, is no longer regarded as necessary to serve other needs, at least not for some.
 ''They may have thought that it was, but it quickly changes when you've got three kids or you want to have two or three,'' said John B. Fahey Jr., a real estate broker who has worked in the area since 1970.
 Convenience is not Litchfield's allure. Isolated from major highways and commuter rail, it is a two-hour trip to New York.
 ''This area is driven by lifestyle, not by location and proximity to an airport,'' Mr. Fahey said.
 Another longtime real estate broker, Edward J. Murphy Jr., said of the newcomers, ''They want a population that's well educated and very cosmopolitan and sophisticated, and No.2, they want peace and quiet and rural country charm.''
 Jeff Savage, 64, an actor who sells tiger maple drop-leaf tables with five-figure price tags at Jeffrey Tillou Antiques on West Street, said, ''You've got all this stuff going on here, yet you go to sleep at night and it's quiet.''
 Litchfield has been a summer destination since early in the 20th century, when industrialization had largely passed it by and vacationers took to its well-preserved rural New England aesthetic, set atop the hills east of the Housatonic River. Cottages, often without heat or insulation, were once abundant. 
 And buyers still come just for weekends and summers. Richard M. Lynn Jr., planning director for the Litchfield Hills Council of Elected Officials, cited census figures showing that the number of seasonal homes increased to 5.5 percent of all housing units in 2000, compared with 3.9 percent in 1990. 
 Yet the census also shows that owner-occupied housing units nudged up to 78.5 percent from 76.5 percent, from 1990 to 2000. And some real-estate agents, laborers and locals say that in the last several years Litchfield has seen a gentle shift, with affluent younger buyers from New York often replacing the aging executives who bought summer homes and eventually turned them into year-round retirement homes. 
 At the same time, residents from Fairfield County have come north as that area has become congested and expensive, either buying second homes or moving altogether. Several people said the terrorist attacks of 2001 had also played a role in driving people from New York toward Litchfield.
 In the process, housing prices have soared, traffic has increased and an inevitable -- and, some say, ironic -- aversion to more change has taken hold. 
 ''There tends to be considerable local resistance to even widening any state roads,'' Mr. Lynn said. ''It sounds strange, but I think that planners in the area will be considered successful if the area looks pretty much the same 50 years from now as it does today.''
 Mr. Lynn noted that the town's population actually declined slightly from 1990 to 2000, to 8,316 from 8,365, but he said it has increased somewhat in the five years since the last census. He said the town averaged an increase of about 67 people a year from 1950 to 2000.
 While cultural change has not necessarily meant population growth in Litchfield, the differences between old and new are obvious. Beyond the buzz over properties on the market for $25 million or more, middle-class housing has jumped more than 50 percent, to a median sale price of about $272,000 in 2004 from $181,000 in 2000, Mr. Lynn said.
 And the historic section of West Street, once a sturdy main strip, is now an elite array of restaurants, clothing shops, real estate agencies and antiques shops. The old stone state courthouse is the only building on the block whose daily business seems immune to gentrification.
 ''Only people from New York City can afford to shop there, is what I heard,'' John Winslow, a metal worker and a Litchfield native, said of the town center.
 Mr. Moraghan, a former group life insurance salesman, moved into his four-bedroom shingled cottage on Prospect Street about 50 years ago, winterizing it by adding insulation and a concrete floor, he said.
 Mr. Moraghan, who reads the sports page most days at the Oliver Wolcott Library, said: ''I have sort of lost touch when I go to the post office and the library. I don't know any people, but my wife knows them all. She belongs to garden clubs and everything.''
 His house, tidy in late June, with verdant bursts of hostas, is dwarfed by those of his neighbors, including television executives and prominent antiques dealers.
 ''I hope the kids will get a good price for it,'' Mr. Moraghan said about his home. ''It's the location, not the house.''
 Selling may be one concern for children who grew up in Litchfield. Staying is another.
 Krista Mahan, 19, grew up in Litchfield and, after initially going to college in Virginia, decided she missed home so much she came back. Now she attends Central Connecticut State University in New Britain and works at Bohemian Pizza, several blocks down West Street from the town center.
 She said when she told her parents she wanted to live in Litchfield after college, ''They said, 'Well, you better get a good job because you're not going to be able to afford to live here.'''
 Ms. Mahan said she also feels the changes in Litchfield on another front, notably from New Yorkers who she said demand a level of service common in Manhattan, perhaps, but not off a country road in Connecticut.
 ''They expect too much,'' she said. ''This is just a little pizza restaurant.''
 Ms. de Dampierre, the author and designer, prefers the pace in Litchfield to New York. She spends about five nights a week here, looking after her daughter and 15-year-old son, who attends private school and is active in soccer. Her husband usually spends four nights here, driving into the city on Monday mornings, heading for their apartment on the Upper East Side, after watching ''Mystery!'' on public television the night before.
 ''We made a very clear decision when our son was starting kindergarten,'' Ms. de Dampierre said of the couple's decision to tilt their lives toward Litchfield. ''It turned out very good.''
 They bought the house in 1999 and have since renovated it, including adding cheetah-print carpeting in the foyer, building the rear balcony and installing wireless Internet access that stretches to the pool house they recently replaced. 
 The couple socializes with neighbors, including the owners of the West Street Grill, a popular restaurant on West Street known for its food and glamorous clients.
 ''It's sophisticated, there's lots of wonderful people and it's not crowded,'' Mr. Mathis said. ''And compared to Greenwich, compared to the Hamptons, it's cheap. 
 ''I haven't been in New York on a Saturday, except under duress, for 25 years,'' he added. ''It's seamless when I'm sitting here.''

Articles in this series will periodically report on ways in which second-home owners are changing small towns.

HEADLINE: The Great Mango War Flares Once More

BYLINE: By SETH KUGEL

 BODY:
Adam Smith probably never tasted a mango. But Smith, the 18th-century Scottish economist, would surely recognize his theories of supply and demand at work on the streets of Jackson Heights, Queens, one heart of the city's fiercely competitive mango market. 
 The price of mangoes can fluctuate wildly. Buy them at Whole Foods Market in Union Square, and they're $1.98 apiece. But if you go to Jackson Heights and buy them in bulk at the grocery stores in the bustling South Asian business district around 74th Street and 37th Avenue, the price drops to 50 cents or less. (Even that is no bargain to immigrant families from South Asia and the Caribbean, many of whom grew up with mango trees in their backyards.) 
Summer is, of course, mango season, and every summer a mango price war rages in the community. This year the battles have been particularly intense, with profit margins for some vendors driven down to virtually nothing.
 In this neighborhood, where cheap mangoes attract shoppers from as far as Connecticut and New Jersey, prices shift weekly, even daily. On a recent afternoon at the Modi Khana market near 72nd Street and 37th Avenue, mangoes were $5 for a crate of 10, almost a rock-bottom price. ''I don't make money,'' said the manager, Arora Arora. ''Just make the happy customers.''
 Abida Aleem, a teacher from Garden City, in Nassau County, was in Modi Khana that afternoon shopping with her husband and 11 year-old son, Asim. Quietly, Ms. Aleem was switching the best mangoes from one crate to another, even trying to slip in an 11th from another crate for her mango-addicted son.
 Further complicating the picture is that Patel Brothers, an Indian market on 74th Street that is traditionally the neighborhood's main vendor of low-priced mangoes, has raised its prices to $9 for a carton of a dozen.
 As if underscoring Patel's commitment to mangoes, the market employs a staff member, Jadeja Mahendra, whose sole job is supervising outdoor mango sales. Mr. Mahendra, a middle-aged Indian immigrant with a gentle sales pitch, has been hawking mangoes for years. ''Sweet mangoes, Kent mangoes,'' he intoned to passers-by in a thick Gujarati accent, scolding those who tried to switch mangoes from one box to the other in search of a perfect collection of fruit.
 But a dozen mangoes for $9 is almost double what is charged at Modi Khana. Harsad Patel, Mr. Mahendra's boss, explained the problem. ''The crop is short, in Mexico,'' Mr. Patel said. ''One crop comes from the east, one crop comes from the west, and they are late on the West Coast.'' He promised that his price would soon sink back to $6 a case. SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: Will Storm And Attacks Weigh on Consumers?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
THE University of Michigan's consumer confidence report, scheduled to be released on Friday, could provide a glimpse of the impact of last week's London bombings on consumer sentiment. 
The survey for the preliminary July report will continue until Thursday, according to Richard T. Curtin, the director of the survey. He said it included an open-ended question that will allow him to determine what kind of effect on sentiment -- if any -- the bombings actually had. He also said that consumer attitudes could be affected by Hurricane Dennis, the first storm of this season to reach hurricane status. Wall Street forecasters are predicting that the preliminary July index will be 95, down from the final June reading of 96, according to Bloomberg.

DATA WATCH -- Before that report on consumer confidence, investors and analysts will have already digested new data on inflation and retail sales in June, and on the trade deficit for May. The industrial production report for June comes out on Friday, too.
 The price data are expected to be relatively restrained, and retail sales and industrial production are predicted to be healthy. Any positive investor reaction to those bits of news could be undermined by fear that the price of crude oil will be stuck in the high $50's or low $60's for some time -- as well as by concerns about terrorism.
 The Consumer Price Index, due Tuesday, is expected to have risen 0.2 percent in June. In addition, the Producer Price Index for finished goods, due Wednesday, is expected to have jumped 0.4 percent. 
 But the gains in the core indexes, excluding increases for food and energy, are expected to be contained, with the core C.P.I. up 0.2 percent and the core P.P.I. up 0.1 percent. 
 Retail sales are forecast to have increased 1 percent last month, after a 0.5 percent decline in May. That would be the second-largest monthly increase this year.
 Industrial production for June is expected to have climbed 0.4 percent, the same as in May. 
 Forecasters expect that the May trade deficit, due Wednesday, will also be the same as it was the previous month, with the red ink totaling $57 billion.

HEADLINE: Turning Point

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY 

 BODY:
OUTSIDE the new Coach outlet store -- where $250 handbags are marked down as much as $100 -- stands a decorative pole ready to display the photographs of Miss Americas 2010 through 2019, a bit of optimism that may seem misplaced these days.
 Along Michigan Avenue, where names like Mikasa, Guess?, Geoffrey Beene and Brooks Brothers now attract hordes of people wielding credit cards, times past are quickly being forgotten.
Few patrons of The Walk -- the outlet mall with the Coach store that opened here last spring -- stop to look at photographs of the toothy, smiling Miss Americas from the 1920's to the present that adorn the many poles. And fewer still stop to think about or even remember when this stretch of Michigan Avenue from Pacific to Baltic Avenues was a collection of boarded-up storefronts where only drugs were bought and sold.
 These days, Coach bags have replaced nickel bags as the neighborhood's currency. 
 Yet in an odd and somewhat unexpected juxtaposition, Miss America's presence here is fading along with the city's nagging legacy of dilapidation and despair. Hotels and casinos are expanding and polishing their images to a high gloss, trendy shops are taking a chance on the newest Atlantic City, and A-list entertainers are putting the place back on their itineraries.
 The irony is that the transformation may come without the event the city has long clung to as evidence of its hard-earned respectability: the Miss America Pageant. 
 Last month, the pageant organization -- cut adrift by the major television networks as ratings continued to plummet -- announced that it had sold the television rights to Country Music Television, a part of the Viacom media empire, and that the date -- at least for this year's pageant -- would be moved from its traditional mid-September slot to January.
 But to many residents here, who for years have provided help, homes and hope to the 84-year-old pageant, what was not stated was as important as everything that was. It is still not known whether the January pageant will be held in Atlantic City or Nashville -- the home of Country Music Television -- or somewhere in between. 
 For now, some officials are quick to deny that Miss America will gather her tiaras and sashes and leave Atlantic City -- where the event was dreamed up by merchants in 1921 to extend the summer vacation season.
 Others have been quick to conclude that, if not this year, then soon enough, Nashville will be the new home of this time-worn icon.
 And at this point, how many people really care? 
 ''Maybe from mere perception by some people that moving Miss America could exacerbate Atlantic City as a loser, it is not a wonderful thing,'' said Joe Weinert, who covered the casino industry for The Press of Atlantic City and is now vice president of the Spectrum Gaming Group and managing editor of the Gaming Industry Observer. ''It is corny and campy, but it has been linked to Atlantic City inextricably for decades.''
 ''The economic impact of it would be minimal,'' Mr. Weinert said. ''The casino industry does not care for the event. It does nothing for their business. It does not bring big players into town. It brings in people who take up hotel rooms and do not gamble much at all.''
 Interestingly, Mr. Weinert's observation was shared by Leonard Horn, a lifelong resident of the area who was chairman of the Miss America Pageant from 1987 until he retired to Tennessee in 1998.
 ''The demographic for Miss America has changed, and it isn't great for casinos,'' said Mr. Horn, who was accused by some -- falsely, he insists -- of having had a hand in the negotiations with Country Music Television. ''It would be a nostalgic loss, but I don't think it would be an economic loss at all.
 It was 1977 when legalized casino gambling came to Atlantic City, and it initially was seen as the elixir that would cure what ailed the crumbling, corrupted resort -- bolstered by the nationally recognized pageant. But in truth, the pageant, in the heart of the Northeastern megalopolis, was a target of many critics who said that time had passed it by. 
 Casino operators -- with the exception of Donald Trump, who has provided floats for the pageant's parade along the Boardwalk -- were at best agnostic when it came to Miss America. And at worst, they resented the hundreds upon hundreds of hotel rooms inhabited for a week by people who did not buy a chip.
 Yet unlikely as it seems, even Arctic Avenue is beginning to shimmer with Geoffrey Beene and Calvin Klein. And the people who for years have worked to try to burnish the image of Atlantic City have awakened -- at least for now -- to the strangest phenomenon: they don't have to work nearly as hard to come up with good news.
 ''Our job is to fill the hotel rooms, and we just have more attractions to fill those rooms,'' said Jeffrey Vasser, executive director of the Atlantic City Convention and Visitors Authority. ''We have the House of Blues opening earlier this summer. We have more events on the Boardwalk and the new beach bars just off it.
 ''When the Borgata does its new expansion, that will be news,'' Mr. Vasser said. ''Then there is Trump, and with the Donald being Donald, that is sure to be noteworthy.''

Thriving Beyond Gambling
 These days, there are 15,000 hotel rooms in Atlantic City, an increase of 4,000 from just three years ago. And expansions at three casinos -- Harrah's, Trump Taj Mahal and the Borgata -- should add 3,000 more in the next three years. Mr. Vasser said about 90 percent of the rooms are occupied every night, even more on weekends, so there is no question that Atlantic City can absorb the new rooms. 
 Perhaps getting ahead of himself, Mr. Vasser said he even envisioned a time when far fewer of them would be comped -- the term for rooms, meals or other amenities given free to preferred customers -- and sold outright as they are in most noncasino resorts, a move that would show Atlantic City was thriving beyond casino gambling. Currently, about 70 percent of the room-nights in casino hotels are comped.
 At the Tropicana, according to Pamela J. Popielarski, the hotel-casino's president and general manager, fewer than half the room-nights will be comped this year, for now the only casino hotel in town below 50 percent.
 What led the hotel to make the move, Ms. Popielarski said, was the opening in April of the Quarter, a 200,000-square-foot space in the Tropicana with 40 upscale shops and restaurants, the largest such nongaming area in town.
 ''Las Vegas showed us that even in a casino town, people want to do more than just gamble,'' she said. ''It is a new customer base, younger and more active. We have to adapt to what they want, and they want to shop more, have nightclubs and restaurants, just do more things.''
 In recent years, Las Vegas has turned the tables, so to speak, on the traditional casino system. Atlantic City and Las Vegas each have 35 million visitors each year. And the cities are relatively close in gaming revenue, with Las Vegas earning $6 billion in 2004 and Atlantic City taking in $4.5 billion. 
 Yet in sharp contrast, visitors to Las Vegas spent $27 billion on nongaming activities in 2004, while that figure came to only $6 billion in Atlantic City -- twice what it was five years earlier, and what Atlantic City hopes to build on.
 ''It is based on the trajectory of the Borgata's success,'' said Curtis Bashaw, head of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority. ''The Borgata was hipper and cooler and had more restaurants and clubs. It proved that people would come to Atlantic City to do other things but gamble.''
 It is Mr. Bashaw's hope that by drawing more visitors to Atlantic City, a more constructive cycle can gain a foothold. The redevelopment authority takes 1.5 percent of the casinos' gross revenue to provide grants for urban renewal projects, primarily but not exclusively in Atlantic County. 
 Since its creation in 1984, the agency has built 1,897 housing units in Atlantic City, and its current major project is $100a million revamping of the building facades along the Boardwalk. It had already provided seed money to refurbish Boardwalk Hall, the traditional home of Miss America, where little was taking place besides the pageant before the renovation three years ago, Mr. Bashaw said, making it more attractive as a site and lifting some of the burden from the pageant.
 ''It has become a stagnant attraction in the static view people had of the town,'' said Mr. Bashaw, who is also a hotel owner in Cape May. ''There are changes happening here, and I think what you see is just the tip of the iceberg. I don't want Miss America to leave, but if she does, we've had Elton John and Bette Midler sell out Boardwalk Hall, and there will be more of that in any case.''
 Nor was Mr. Bashaw the only one with an unsentimental view of the possibility that Miss America Pageant could leave Atlantic City.

'Its Time Has Passed'
 For 32 years, William and Petie Subin volunteered their time and their energy -- she as a chaperone and on television production and he as head of security and on the Miss America board -- before stopping last year.
 ''It was time to leave,'' said Mrs. Subin, who lives in nearby Margate. ''The pageant has changed. If it moves, it's not going to matter to anyone except the people in Atlantic City. You would go every year and it would be like a sorority or fraternity reunion. But it is like a flower growing. It blooms and then, at some point, it is over.''
 ''The casinos never supported it and now its time has passed,'' she said. ''There are a lot of things going on in Atlantic City and with Bobby Levy, a lifelong resident, coming in as mayor, people have a lot of hope.''
 But this being Atlantic City -- where dreams have often been left at the water's edge -- the optimism is tinged with a well-earned wariness. 
 Craig Calloway, the City Council president, supported Mr. Levy, the head of the city's emergency management office and beach patrol, in his victorious race against the incumbent mayor, Lorenzo Langford, in the Democratic primary, which is tantamount to winning the general election in this overwhelmingly Democratic city.
 While Mr. Calloway is confident of Atlantic City's eventual revival, he is concerned that it will not reach his primarily black and Hispanic constituency in the poorer sections of this city of 40,000 residents.
 ''Atlantic City is on the verge of some really great things and definitely a lot of opportunities for business and for the casinos,'' he said. ''We're in the process of making those good things happen, but we need it to come to the working poor people. That is what hasn't happened at this point.''
 As for Miss America, he dismissed the pageant as ''just an item of nostalgia.''
 ''You talk to people in my community about Miss America,'' Mr. Calloway said, ''and they are thinking about jobs and shopping and education. She's way down the road.''
 Mr. Horn, who was born in Atlantic City in 1936, has been down that road several times in the cyclical history of the resort and has his own views. 
 ''What is interesting to me is that there was a divergence in the ascendance of Miss America and Atlantic City,'' he said. ''Throughout the 1960's, the Miss America Pageant was at the height of its glory and Atlantic City was in its depths.'' 
 He recounted the story of the 1964 Democratic National Convention, which was supposed to be a shot in the arm for Atlantic City but instead was a disaster. 
 ''All of these reporters stayed in these rooms, and the hotels had not been spending money keeping them in good shape,'' he said. ''They wrote story after story about rats and whatnot and after that the city took a nosedive. But as Atlantic City was struggling then, Miss America was soaring.''

A Bumpy Upswing
 Yet in the last decade or so, Mr. Horn said, as Atlantic City enjoyed a bumpy upswing, Miss America lost its way.
 ''When I was there, I tried to move it to Disney World, which was owned by the same parent as ABC, which broadcast the show,'' he said. ''I knew there would be no support by the board, though. I thought of Nashville, too, but that wouldn't have happened. Maybe now is the time.''
 Cathy Burke, who owns the Irish Pub, just off the Boardwalk at St. James Place, hopes that that is not the case.
 ''I know it is old-fashioned, but Atlantic City still needs some of that,'' Ms. Burke said. ''I am in favor of The Walk and all the new retail, and that is fine. But if we get rid of Miss America, we will just be another casino town. Some traditions are worth keeping, and I think this is one of them.''
 To Mr. Weinert of the Gaming Industry Observer, changing the time of the pageant from September to January -- assuming the pageant remains in Atlantic City -- could perhaps be embraced by the casino owners.
 ''Mid-January is a slow time,'' he said. ''From a practical standpoint, that would give Atlantic City and the casino industry a highly visible off-season event. On the other hand, you can't parade down the Boardwalk then and see Miss America frolic in the surf.''

HEADLINE: Mercedes Quality: Back on Track? 

BYLINE: By CHERYL JENSEN

 BODY:
COMPLAINTS about the quality and reliability of Mercedes-Benz products have dulled the company's once-sparkling image, but the automaker seems to be regaining some luster in closely watched surveys.
 While Mercedes once scored among the best automakers in quality, it started slipping in the late 1990's, eventually landing near the bottom in some studies. Many of the problems stemmed from glitches in new, technologically sophisticated electronics systems; such gremlins have also plagued other luxury automakers, including Mercedes's German competitors.
But the M-Class S.U.V. was another culprit, scoring poorly for a variety of reasons almost from the time it went on sale in 1997. 
 Mercedes quality ''was exceptionally good'' in the 1997 Initial Quality Study by J.D. Power & Associates, said Chance Parker, the firm's executive director for product research and analysis. ''Its score was significantly better than the industry average and would have been among the best nameplates at that time,'' Mr. Parker said. 
 The Initial Quality Study looks at problems that arise in the first 90 days after a car is purchased, and indicates the potential for longer-term trouble.
 Two years later, in the 1999 survey, the M-Class ranked last among luxury S.U.V.'s.
 After the M-Class provoked owner complaints and received low quality scores, Mercedes set out to improve processes at the new plant near Tuscaloosa, Ala., where it was built. In the 2004 study, the M-Class shot up to second place in its segment, but it fell back to seventh place (among 11 vehicles) this year.
 The 1998 M-Class was also largely responsible for a big blow to Mercedes's quality image in a different J.D. Power survey, the Vehicle Dependability Study, which looks at problems with vehicles over the previous three years. In the 2002 survey, the Mercedes brand dropped from 10th to 16th place, falling below the industry average for the first time since the study began in 1989. 
 Mr. Parker said there was evidence that Mercedes's overall quality was improving. The brand has been doing ''significantly better again,'' he said, in initial quality studies. 
 For instance, Mercedes tied Cadillac for fifth place among automotive brands in the Initial Quality Study this year (trailing Lexus, Jaguar, BMW and Buick). Mercedes had ranked 10th in 2004 and 15th in 2003.
 Mr. Parker said Mercedes's gains were bolstered by sharp improvements for the M-Class and the compact C-Class line. But he said it was too soon to reach conclusions about long-term dependability.
 Mercedes's initial-quality problems occurred mainly in two areas, J.D. Power says. First are ''traditional malfunctions and failures'' of features and controls like wipers, cruise control and navigation system. Second are craftsmanship issues like ill-fitting panels, squeaks and rattles.
 These are not catastrophic failures, but they disappoint owners. David Champion, the auto testing director for Consumer Reports, recalled an S-Class sedan that the magazine tested in 2003. A button that controlled functions related to the radio, navigation system and climate controls kept sticking and had to be pried out. ''Its a 2-cent part that creates mega-frustration,'' he said.
 Daniel Gorrell, vice president of Strategic Vision, a San Diego research firm, said ''long-term durability issues'' had hurt Mercedes. ''They tend to become more bothersome after three months, particularly with electronic failures, because they are so electronically oriented,'' he said.
 As part of a global initiative, Mercedes spent $645 million in the first quarter to fix quality issues. It also invested $600 million to expand the Alabama plant, where the new R-Class will also be built. 
 Still, Mercedes has already recalled 7,200 M-Class utilities, on sale since March, for problems with a power steering hose clamp.
 Whatever improvements Mercedes is making, they may not be enough to keep up. Although the brand's score jumped 26 points in the J.D. Power initial quality study in 2004, it gained only 2 points this year while Lexus improved by 6, said Art Spinella, president of CNW Marketing Research in Bandon, Ore. ''So even though Mercedes has gotten better, the gap keeps widening,'' Mr. Spinella said. ''Now they are as good as Cadillac. Buick is better. Other people are getting better faster.''
 Despite the poor showing in several reliability studies, Mercedes insists it has history on its side. ''Of the cars we have sold since 1955, 72 percent are still on the road,'' said Rob Moran, a Mercedes spokesman. ''So that's a pretty good measure in terms of reliability and speaks to the longevity of the models.''

HEADLINE: Cal-Mex

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL RICH. 
Nathaniel Rich, the author of ''San Francisco Noir,'' is an editor at The Paris Review.

 BODY:

MUSIC OF THE MILL
By Luis J. Rodriguez.
308 pp. Rayo/
HarperCollins Publishers.
$24.95.

THE PEOPLE OF PAPER
By Salvador Plascencia.
245 pp. McSweeney's Books.
$22.
 In Luis J. Rodriguez's first novel, ''Music of the Mill,'' one character explains that ''before the borders came, we were all in one land. The Mexican migration patterns to the U.S. have been going on for tens of thousands of years.'' Rodriguez is being generous, of course. For until the borders did come, after the Mexican War that ended in 1848, California, Nevada, Utah and parts of four other southwestern states had all been Mexican territory.
 Both ''Music of the Mill'' and ''The People of Paper,'' Salvador Plascencia's first novel, offer perspectives on the Mexican-American experience in and around the city originally known as El Pueblo de Los Angeles, though the two authors' techniques could not be more dissimilar. In ''Music of the Mill,'' Rodriguez provides a brisk history of the last half of the American 20th century through the story of the Salcidos, a Chicano family living in the old industrial corridor of southeast Los Angeles. In ''The People of Paper,'' Plascencia creates a mythic, alternative history of the town of El Monte, which is east of Los Angeles, by blending fragments of American culture with Mexican folklore. Both novels, different though their approaches are, portray Los Angeles's Mexican-American communities with a grandeur and dignity that conventional accounts of the region's history often deny them.
 ''Music of the Mill'' reads like a fictional sequel to ''Always Running,'' Rodriguez's witty and brutally vivid memoir about growing up as a gang member in East Los Angeles. That book ends with Rodriguez, at 20, leaving gang life behind and setting off to work in a steel mill. ''Music of the Mill'' begins with the story of how Procopio Salcido, an 18-year-old Yaqui Indian from Sonora, finds a job in a steel mill after fleeing across the border in 1943. We later follow Procopio's son, Johnny, as he battles for civil rights and union representation for Chicano steelworkers in the early 1970's. The final section is narrated by Johnny's troubled daughter, Azucena, who comes of age in the 1980's, after the mill has closed and the neighborhood has deteriorated. But the mill, operated by a company called Nazareth Steel, is the largest character of them all. For Rodriguez, Nazareth comes to represent the promise and tragedy of the American dream. The mill provides excellent salaries, affordable housing and extensive health care, though its toxic boiler tanks and infernal furnaces lead its workers to alcoholism, depression, violence and premature death. As Rodriguez memorably describes it: ''It's a cold lover that will fail to recognize you the day after a sweat-filled night. It's a great mother who often denies her babies suckling, an earth monster who can devour you as soon as birth you.'' 
 The steel mill, with all the symbolic weight it carries, is so great a mother, in fact, that it tends to overwhelm the story of the Salcidos. This is particularly true when Rodriguez uses Johnny's experience in the mill to explore such vast subjects as labor union corruption, battles for civil rights and equal opportunity employment, the decline of American industry and the gradual transformation of Los Angeles's Mexican neighborhoods into dangerous ghettos. And while Rodriguez's colloquial language suited the brisk, episodic narrative of ''Always Running'' and the short stories in his fine collection, ''The Republic of East L.A.,'' he too often undermines the epic scope of this grander project with slack metaphors (''To Darlene, Johnny's kindness is like water to a thirsty woman in a parched desert'') and platitudes (''When that mill died, it's like a good part of us died as well''). Nevertheless, the novel gives us sympathetic portrayals of characters who, despite being worn down by racism and economic oppression, still manage to hope and stumble and love.
 In ''The People of Paper,'' Plascencia mythologizes his hometown, El Monte, drawing inspiration from the fables he learned as a child at his grandparents' farm in Jalisco. Among the novel's dozens of overlapping vignettes are those of a woman who escapes to El Monte when her Mexican town suddenly, and inexplicably, turns to dust; a soothsaying infant who transmits his prophecies through ESP; a girl obsessed with sucking limes, who dies of ''citric poisoning,'' only to be resurrected several days later by a miracle; an origami woman constructed from old newspapers, whose kisses give her lovers nasty paper cuts on their tongues and their other extremities; Rita Hayworth (nee Margarita Carmen Cansino and, in Plascencia's version, born in Jalisco instead of Brooklyn), who is mocked by the lettuce pickers in Jalisco when she abandons them for Hollywood; and a man who persuades a local gang to wage war against the planet Saturn, which he suspects of reading the townspeople's thoughts. (Saturn is later revealed to be the author himself who, alas, emerges as a central character in his own novel.)
 As wondrous and comically inventive as many of these episodes are, they never cohere into a single, larger story, a problem that Plascencia's exhausting use of typographical gimcrackery -- blotted-out text; razored-out text; sideways text; text split into as many as five columns across two pages, each column representing a different character's narrative -- cannot camouflage. Still, Plascencia has done a nice job of creating a radiant, peculiar world that forms a convincing borderland between Hollywood and Jalisco. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review
