HEADLINE: Kitchen Sage

BYLINE: By Jonathan Reynolds

 BODY:
There are a baby's handful of people in this city you can point to and say, ''That's who folks come to New York to be'' -- Mayor Mike from Boston, Bobby Short from Danville, Ill., and Kate Spade from Kansas City, to name a few. Kurt Andersen from Omaha, to name another. Andersen, 50, whose resume is as diverse as Leonardo's, has been a literary force in town from the moment in 1976 that he stepped off the plane with a Harvard B.A. under his arm and walked into The Daily News to work as a copy boy. He lasted a day before fleeing to NBC to write radio copy for Gene Shalit. Since then, he has been the editor of and is currently a columnist at New York magazine, was a writer at The New Yorker and co-founder and editor of the notoriously punchy and nose-tweaking Spy magazine, has published one novel with a second in the wings (''Wonderstruck,'' due out next spring) and is currently host of ''Studio 360,'' a weekly public radio show that recently won a Peabody. 
 As if that weren't enough, he miraculously manages to cook almost every night for his wife, Anne Kreamer (a contributing editor at Martha Stewart Living), and their two attractive daughters, Lucy, 15, and Kate, 17, at the four-story town house they've owned for 16 years in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn. At age 6, Kurt discovered the magical realism of baking -- notably cinnamon buns and Swiss chocolate pie -- and he never let up.
 ''I really learned to cook from my very rural grandmother,'' he said as he chopped first a red, then a yellow, pepper for the chutney he would be serving family and friends -- a total of eight -- just 90 minutes later. ''She made the thinnest, crunchiest ginger cookies ever -- my own personal madeleines -- and showed me that cooking could be fun, not just copying from recipes.'' 
 Andersen is 6-foot-2 and slim, and speaks with understated passion about most things but particularly about dinner with family. ''We have dinner with our daughters most nights of the week'' -- about five out of seven, Anne would later amend -- ''because we think it's good for all of us.'' He smiled. ''And incidentally, we recently heard about that study that said kids who ate dinner with their parents regularly did better on their SAT's than ones who didn't. Dinner with family was more predictive than economic background, divorce or ethnicity.'' 
 Dinner tonight would consist of a couple of summer classics -- charcoal-grilled tuna steaks with mango chutney and a berry tart he farmed out to Lucy, an aspiring baker -- and two unclassic-but-soon-should-be's, fried sage leaves and deep-fried okra. (Okraphobes hold the phone; this'll convert you). He managed all this while keeping up a lively conversation on topics dearest to every New Yorker's heart, native or immigrant: politics; the arts; the trickiness of screenplays; and food.
 ''I like red onions for this chutney -- they give it a sharper taste and some contrast to the sweetness of the mango and peppers,'' he said as he left-handedly diced one in the airy kitchen that abuts their ground floor dining room on one end and a verdant city garden on the other. Lucy formed her tart shell -- she would later line it with mascarpone and whipped cream, then big, fat berries -- then curled up in the corner and perused ''Essentials of Baking'' from the gang at Williams-Sonoma. 
 Kurt started slicing two pounds of okra into mathematically perfect 1/2-inch rounds. Okra pods terrify most Northerners, largely because their interiors can be slimy (the okra, not the Yankees, depending), with a texture not unlike an especially gooey oyster. ''It's a strange little vegetable,'' Kurt said. ''People either don't know it or think they won't like it. I never had it growing up in Nebraska, but a friend made it in bread crumbs . . . fantastic!''
 He mixed the okra bits with a couple of eggs, a little milk and salt and pepper. ''If you slice them thicker, you get more of an okra sensation and less of a French fry,'' he said. ''I've tried it with flour and wheat germ, but crumbs are the best. And I've tried frying it in olive oil, but with corn oil the family gave me more praise than usual,'' he added, clearly heartened by their approval.
 Anne entered with a pile of sage leaves freshly picked from their garden and ranging in size from dime to silver dollar. She is diminutive and temporarily blond with a quick smile and very alert eyes. Lucy baked her tart shell. Kurt gently patted the leaves dry, b-a-r-e-l-y dusted them with flour and sauteed them in a thin film of olive oil, 30 seconds per side, making sure they didn't touch. ''The trick with sage is, not too much moisture so it doesn't get all about the flour. Sometimes you get just the right amount in the leaf.'' 
 We had a fast glass of wine in the garden and praised the tasty fragility of the leaves -- he could have sauteed an entire sage bush, they were so good. Then Kurt quickly (but with understated quickness) heated to shimmering an inch and a half of corn oil, rolled the sliced okra in bread crumbs and gently immersed them in the oil. Almost immediately, they began bonking and bubbling away like oil soup. Lucy removed the tart shell from the oven. It smelled heavenly. ''Mmmm, I just want to go straight to the pie!'' Anne said.
 ''That's what you say now,'' Lucy said, because she's a teenager. 
 With one eye on the bouncing okra, Kurt grilled the tuna steaks and covered them with the chutney. The tuna had a nice charcoaled whiff to it, and the relish gave moisture and a lively goose of flavor. The okra -- don't cancel your subscription now -- was scrumptious. Lucy's fresh-tasting tart revealed a potential Francois Payard, and as befitted our crowd, we discussed subjects of the now, ranging from the exhibit at the Japan Society examining that culture's recent embrace of kawaii, or ''cuteness'' (which puzzled everyone at the table), to the Penn Gillette documentary ''The Aristocrats'' (brilliant and funny), to the redesign of ''The Daily Show'' set (are they getting rid of the desk?), to the unique American specimen who is Jane Fonda.
 Earlier, Kurt said, smiling, ''My Nebraska dream of New York was to live in a brownstone -- that was because of 'The Patty Duke Show.' '' But I don't remember a single episode in which Patty ate fried okra and tackled the world. 

INTO THE FOLD
This splendid wood spatula, which looks as if it could paddle a small canoe, is about 14 inches long. In France, it is known as a crepe spatula and is designed to slip under thin, delicate crepes and flip them without incident. It was a gift to the Andersens, and they use it, Kurt said, for ''any 'folding' -- in batters, souffles and frostings -- a word and cooking activity I happen to love.'' Crepe spatulas are $2.99 to $11.50 at goldaskitchen.com, fantes.com and finerkitchens.com.

Fried Sage Leaves
Olive oil
Sage leaves, rinsed and patted dry
All-purpose flour
Salt and pepper.
 In a medium skillet, heat 1/4 inch oil over medium-high heat until hot enough to toast a bread crumb in 30 seconds. Toss sage in flour, shake vigorously to remove as much flour as possible and fry, 30 seconds per side. Drain on paper towels, sprinkle with salt and pepper and serve with cocktails.

Deep-Fried Okra
1 large egg
1/3 cup milk
2 cups dry bread crumbs
3 cups corn oil
1 pound okra, rinsed and cut into 1/2-inch pieces
Salt and pepper.
 1. In a large bowl, whisk together egg and milk. Place bread crumbs in a second large bowl. Heat oil in a heavy 12-inch skillet over medium-high heat until oil is hot enough to toast a bread crumb in 30 seconds.
 2. Toss half the okra in the egg mixture until thoroughly coated (use your hands or, if you must, a spoon). Pick up large handfuls (or slotted spoonfuls) of the okra pieces, letting the excess liquid drip back into the bowl. Transfer okra to the bowl with bread crumbs and toss until coated.
 3. Add okra to hot oil and cook until well browned, about 5 minutes. Remove okra with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. Repeat with remaining okra. Season with salt and pepper and serve hot. Serves 6.

Charcoal-Grilled Tuna Steaks With Mango Chutney
68-ounce tuna steaks, each 1- 1/2 inches thick
1 tablespoon soy sauce
1 tablespoon olive oil
1/2 cup orange juice or blood orange juice (Oranfrizer brand preferred but not essential)
2 tablespoons grated ginger
1 mango, cut into 1/3-inch cubes
1 large yellow bell pepper, cut into 1/3-inch cubes
1 large red bell pepper, cut into 1/3-inch cubes
1 red onion, cut into 1/3-inch cubes
Salt and pepper
Leaves from 1 bunch cilantro, chopped.
 1. Rub steaks with soy sauce and oil and marinate for 30 to 60 minutes.
 2. In a large bowl, whisk together orange juice and ginger. Add mango, bell peppers and onion and set aside.
 3. Prepare a charcoal grill for high-heat cooking. Season tuna with salt and pepper and grill, turning once, until desired doneness, about 2 minutes per side for rare, 3 minutes per side for medium-rare. Stir cilantro into mango mixture, season lightly with salt to taste and serve over tuna steaks. Serves 6. 

All recipes adapted from Kurt Andersen.

PERSON: John J. Ford Jr

HEADLINE: John J. Ford Jr., 81, Dies; Coin Dealer and Collector

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
John J. Ford Jr., a coin dealer and collector known for catalogs that brought new clarity to numismatics and whose collections, including the earliest American coins and prized Confederate pennies, have dazzled recent auctiongoers, died on July 7 at a nursing home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81.
 Susan Dobbins, his daughter, confirmed the death.
The scale and completeness of Mr. Ford's collecting have emerged as 11 of as many as 20 auctions have been held to sell off his esoteric collections, which included the notes of Massachusetts issued in 1690, the oldest coins issued by the Continental Congress and African chiefs' medals. 
 Michael Hodder, a numismatic consultant, said bidders had already spent $35 million on the Ford collections, and the final total may rival the three auctions of the collection of Louis E. Eliasburg Sr., who assembled every known American coin. These exceeded $55 million.
 Francis D. Campbell, the librarian of the American Numismatic Society, said the sales have expanded appreciation of Mr. Ford.
 ''It's going to settle in that he was more important than we thought he was,'' he said.
 Mr. Ford's impact on the field has been better known in the small circle of its professionals, particularly his catalogs for the New Netherlands Coin Company, which he partly owned. His meticulous descriptions of grades, colors and other qualities were unprecedented, wrote Harvey R. Stack, owner of Stack's, which is auctioning Mr. Ford's collections.
 Not only did the catalogs enable people to bid with more confidence, but they also represented some of the highest numismatic scholarship in the United States, Mr. Hodder said. He explained that American numismatists are largely restricted to commercial publications, unlike the approach in Europe, where numismatics museums and university courses are common. In an introduction to a catalog, Q. David Bowers, a well-known numismatist, called Mr. Ford one of the ''most influential figures in American numismatics.''
 He was most prominent in the 1950's and 1960's, when coin collecting, once known as ''the hobby of kings'' greatly broadened its appeal in a booming postwar economy. It trails only stamp collecting in participants, but leads in money spent.
 Mr. Ford's career had controversy. He reversed the industry's practice of overrating coins up for auction. He designated coins ''very fine'' that others might rate ''extremely fine.'' It packed the room, he said.
 Mr. Ford was involved in one of the longest-running, vitriolic disputes in the history of American numismatics. Some prominent experts charged that he was part of a scheme to sell fake gold and silver bars, falsely claiming they came from the American West.
 Mr. Ford, backed by other authorities, categorically denied any fraud. But, when not on the subject of the accusations, he could not help philosophizing.
 ''Ever since the first coin was sold to anybody, somebody has lied about it,'' he said in an interview with the magazine of Heritage Galleries and Auctioneers.
 John Jay Ford Jr. was born on March 5, 1924, in Hollywood, where his father liked to socialize with movie people. The elder Mr. Ford, a scientist and inventor, lost all his money in business failures and retreated to Queens. He borrowed haircut money from his teenage son.
 The son, already a stamp collector, bought his first old currency from a shop on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn. He paid 15 cents for a Confederate bill that years later fetched $200.
 He quit his paper route and got a job as a delivery boy for Stack's. By the time he was drafted into the Army, he had a thriving business making his own numismatic deals as he went about his errands.
 He was regarded as a wonder, having virtually memorized ''United States Pattern, Trial and Experimental Pieces'' by Edgar H. Adams and William H. Woodin, then a standard numismatic resource. Mr. Hodder likened this to memorizing all of a day's baseball box scores, only more complicated. 
 After serving as an Army cryptographer, Mr. Ford did other kinds of work before finding his way back to coin shops. He soon joined Charles Wormser at New Netherlands, becoming a partner in two years.
 Mr. Ford discovered and cultivated Walter Breen, often heralded as the genius of numismatics. Mr. Breen, who went on to write what became an industry bible, teamed with Mr. Ford to write New Netherlands' famous catalogs.
 Wayte Raymond, one of America's legendary numismatists, hired Mr. Ford to help him with in-depth research at the National Archives. Mr. Ford also worked closely with F.C.C. Boyd, long a commanding personality in the coin field. He handled both men's estates, giving him a first chance at great treasures.
 Mr. Ford is survived by his wife, Joan; his daughters Susan Dobbins of Scottsdale, Leslie Sanderson of Prescott, Ariz., and Kimberly Moon of Haddonfield, N.J., eight grandchildren; and one great-granddaughter.
 He is remembered for the no-nonsense bomb shelter full of valuable coins and currencies in the basement of the Long Island home where he long lived, not to mention his Cuban cigars. His stories, like the one about taking a $67,000 check written on toilet paper from a tipsy oilman are still savored: it was the only paper in the hotel room.
 Mr. Ford's enthusiasm for collecting and trading spilled into such varied fields as the medals presidents gave Indian chiefs, the badges slaves wore when they were rented out for day work, Civil War revolvers and an ashtray owned by Hitler.
 At dinner, his trading often continued, as he offered, say, two radishes for three olives.

HEADLINE: Las Vegas's Mayor Trying to Attract a Pro Team

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, July 16 

 BODY:
Mayor Oscar Goodman is obsessed with showgirls. To secure a long interview, he suggested, ''Bring showgirls!'' 
 To lure a Major League Baseball team to Las Vegas, he took two showgirls (and an Elvis impersonator) to the winter meetings in Anaheim, Calif., in 2004. To celebrate his city's being named as host of the 2008 winter meetings on Thursday, he squired two showgirls to Cashman Field, the local minor league park. 
Where does he get them? 
 ''I come from a background where we take the Fifth,'' said Goodman, once a celebrated mob lawyer who played his premayoral self in the film ''Casino'' and his current self in the television series ''CSI'' and ''Las Vegas.''
 That Goodman employs showgirls as alluring economic development tools should not be construed as a lack of seriousness about his goal to attract a major league sports team to the city that has plenty of other diversions. He doesn't care which sport, he just wants one of them, and he was willing to play the fool with his showgirls-and-Elvis stunt in Anaheim. Then, ''my good friend Tommy Lasorda'' kissed him, and friends like Jack McKeon greeted him warmly.
 ''They legitimized me,'' Goodman, the self-professed ''happiest mayor in the world,'' said Friday during an interview in his 10th-floor downtown office.
 Before entering his cluttered inner sanctum, visitors must pass a five-foot-high, diamond-shaped ''Welcome to Fabulous Mayor Oscar Goodman's Office'' sign, a replica of the famous Las Vegas, Nevada, sign that has greeted people along the Strip here since 1959. A sign over the door boasts that electricity for the sign's blinking lights is not being paid by taxpayers.
 ''It costs 11 cents a day,'' he said.
 A star with his name on it is attached to the door to his bathroom (where a large caricature of hizzoner awaits inside). His supply closet is filled with boxes containing little bottles of his favorite gin, Bombay Sapphire (with small caricatures of a martini-wielding mayor taped to them), which he endorsed a few years ago. Four bobblehead dolls bearing his bearded likeness wobble on a bookcase. 
 From a plastic sheet on his desk he pulls a photograph -- one that shows him during his recent stint as a guest photographer for Playboy.
 ''No other mayor did that!'' he said, showing the picture of him photographing Irina Voronina.
 From his amusement park/office, Goodman can see the 61-acre tract that he envisions as the home of an arena or a stadium. He objects to such a facility rising anywhere else, like miles away on the Strip, where the glitziest casinos operate, which is not part of the Las Vegas that he is the mayor of.
 He said he knew how he would finance a stadium or an arena, but he would not divulge it. 
 ''It will be cutting edge, and make everyone happy,'' he said.
 He added: ''Other mayors see sports as a vehicle for economic vitality. But we're booming. We've got a new person coming to town every six minutes. The missing part is a sense of belonging, a sense of self.''
 Boxing matches, like Saturday night's Bernard Hopkins-Jermain Taylor middleweight bout, ''give outsiders a sense of what Las Vegas is about,'' he said. 
 ''I'm talking about a sense of place for the people who live here,'' he added.
 Without any commitments from any teams to move to the desert, Goodman is pinning his intermediate hopes on persuading the National Basketball Association to hold its 2007 All-Star Game here. Gaming regulators in Nevada have agreed to suspend betting on the game at sports books as a condition of the league's approval. The local convention and visitors authority has authorized the city's $4.5 million bid.
 The idea came from George Maloof, who co-owns the Sacramento Kings, with his brother Gavin, and the Palms hotel and casino near the Strip. ''I laughed,'' Goodman said. ''I thought it was a long shot.''
 It is being considered, among bids from other cities. Mike Bass, a league spokesman, would say only that ''The 2007 All-Star Game bids are still under review, with no time frame determined to make the decision.'' 
 Bob Dupuy, the president of Major League Baseball, said that beneath Goodman's glitter, ''he's very committed to bringing major league sports to Las Vegas'' and that ''the city has a chance for a team in the future.''
 But that future might be far off unless casinos agree to suspend all gambling on baseball games, something they were unwilling to do before baseball moved the Montreal Expos to Washington, not Las Vegas.
 Goodman is 65 and a native Philadelphian who is a disciple of classic Vegas fun: showgirls; his fondness for heavy drinking (he recently told a fourth-grade class that if he could have only one thing on a desert island, it would be gin); and his love of sports gambling. He said Friday that he bet on every baseball game.
 ''I'll bet on anything that moves,'' he said. 
 Goodman said any state that policed its casinos and sports books as rigidly as Nevada did would be the safest place for a major league team. 
 ''I represented people accused of fixing games,'' he said. ''Invariably, they got caught by regulators who saw unusual movement on the lines.''
 Goodman has two years left on his second term, and said he hopes that in that time, a decision to bring a team to the city will have been made. Assuming a third four-year term, he insisted that a team will have moved here by 2011.
 ''I can make things happen as a lawyer,'' he said. ''I can persuade a jury or a judge. But as a mayor, I have to rely on other people to get this done. A team has to call me. If I get the call, and have the fish, shame on me if I don't pull it in. Right now, I have my chum out there.''

HEADLINE: Dude, You're Getting A Loan

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
ON any list of tech-stock hotties, Dell Inc. would certainly rank right up there. Dell, the computer powerhouse, reported revenue of $13.4 billion in the quarter that ended April 29, up 16 percent from a year earlier, and net income of $934 million, a 28 percent jump. Although its shares are down 2.8 percent this year, at $40.96, Dell is trading at a ritzy price-to-earnings ratio of 30, well above the average of 18 for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. 
 One of the fastest-growing elements of Dell's smashing direct-sales model is its financing business. Loans or leases from Dell Financial Services to Dell customers have soared 36 percent, on average, in each of the last six years and are now growing at twice the rate of Dell's overall revenue. 
This business is a natural for Dell, which has flourished by eliminating middlemen wherever it can. Its financing operation is a joint venture with CIT Group Inc., a financial services concern, and generated revenue of $1.5 billion for Dell in the most recent quarter. In the 2005 fiscal year, which ended last January, Dell Financial Services made $5.6 billion in loans and leases. Dell owns 70 percent of the venture.
 For years, Dell profited only on finder's fees it received when it referred a borrower to the joint venture. But now the company is expanding its role: it has set up a special-purpose entity that will profit by packaging and selling one-quarter of the loans or leases originated at Dell Financial in the current fiscal year. And it recently revised its deal with CIT. Now Dell has the right to buy the venture outright in three years. 
 To some degree, Dell's foray into financing is just another example of its quest for profit growth. But as one respected analyst has noted, Dell's financing business brings with it the potential for greater risks. While Dell has rarely disappointed its investors over the years, they should nevertheless be alert to the risks that captive financing units present to nonfinance companies. 
 The analyst in question is Toni Sacconaghi, at Sanford C. Bernstein in New York. He said that while financing transactions were now a very small contributor to Dell's earnings -- an estimated $80 million in operating profits from the business in fiscal 2005, or 2.5 cents a share -- five years from now, the finance business could generate $500 million in annual operating profits for Dell.
 The trouble is, the landscape is littered with manufacturers that, in trying to propel product sales, pushed their financing units to make risky loans. Recall, for example, the crippling losses at Lucent Technologies generated by loosey-goosey vendor financing during the tech bubble. 
 Aggressive consumer lending can be equally perilous. Consider Gateway Inc., a former highflier in personal computers that began a full-throttle finance program in 2000. According to a lawsuit filed against the company in 2003 by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Gateway used the finance program to mask declining product sales. The company settled without admitting or denying wrongdoing.
 Gateway's financing program was aimed at consumers who had been denied loans by the company before the program started. Although Gateway initially intended to finance only $10 million of such dubious loans, according to the suit, as computer sales slipped, the company made $30 million in risky loans to meet a revenue target. 
 Losses on the loans were soon clocked at around 35 percent, according to the S.E.C. In 2001, Gateway took a $100 million charge to reflect the troubled loans. 
 No one is predicting that Dell will follow Gateway's hazardous path. After all, Dell's market share is not declining; in April, its share of the global personal computer market was 18.5 percent, a company best. 
 But the fact remains that when a third party helps oversee such lending, as CIT does now, credit discipline is more likely to be maintained. When Dell buys out CIT, investors will have to be persuaded that credit standards will not be compromised. 
 ''To the degree that Dell takes total control of it, they have to make sure they have the proper expertise in credit scoring and that they are not going to be bullied by the product organization,'' Mr. Sacconaghi said. ''You really want the financing subsidiary to be arm's-length.''
 Brian MacDonald, Dell's treasurer, said that the company was well aware of the risks and had structured the business accordingly. For example, the finance company does not report to Dell's sales executives. ''We'll make sure we have the appropriate checks and balances,'' he said. 
 Last week, Dell hired a veteran executive from MBNA, the credit card concern, to run its financial business, Mr. MacDonald said. 
 Dell could offload some of the risks associated with financing by packaging its loans into securities and selling them to investors, a strategy it now uses in its venture with CIT. 
 But there are risks in this business as well. If the market for such asset-backed securities dried up, Dell would have to hold onto the loans, taking on default risk. 
 ''If we had problems selling into the asset-backed market we would have to fund those originations some other way,'' Mr. MacDonald said. ''But we have an option to fund, not an obligation to fund.'' 
 At the moment, the special-purpose entity set up by Dell does not have to make any public filings. As a result, it is difficult for investors to track the operation. 
 Dell also intends to keep more loans on its balance sheet, although Mr. MacDonald declined to specify a percentage. Dell has a mountain of cash -- almost $6 billion as of the most recent quarter. Deploying cash to make loans, Mr. Sacconaghi said, is not in the best interests of Dell's shareholders. Better to buy back shares or pay dividends.
 Clearly, Dell's shift into lending may soup up profits and please investors. But there is no denying that Dell shareholders will have to monitor the financing business closely to satisfy themselves that the risks do not outweigh the rewards.
 ''I think they're doing it fairly prudently, but a financing business in and of itself bears some risk,'' Mr. Sacconaghi said. ''You really don't get something for nothing.''

HEADLINE: A Super Super (He's a Super Saver) Buys a Co-op

BYLINE: By PENELOPE GREEN

 BODY:
''SAVING money was easy for me,'' Sam Vassallo said, ''because I'm very cheap.''
 Mr. Vassallo, 37, was sitting in his new living room, which gleamed with fresh paint, a new parquet floor, a restored onyx fireplace surround and beveled glass French doors. Beyond were the dining room; an enormous open kitchen with handmade cherry wood cabinets, a wine fridge and a Thermador stove; and the television room, three bathrooms and three bedrooms of Mr. Vassallo's exquisitely renovated, 2,000-square-foot Riverside Drive apartment. It is a new home for himself, his wife, Rose, and their growing family, Evie, almost 2, and Sal, 3 months next week.
Like many recent Manhattan homeowners, Mr. Vassallo bought his apartment for its asking price, $1.45 million, last September -- a good portion of which he paid in cash. But unlike, say, a midlevel investment banker, whose bonus last year might have hovered under $1 million, Mr. Vassallo earned his money the old fashioned way, one dollar at a time. 
 A soft-spoken and gently humorous man, Mr. Vassallo is a skilled carpenter, electrician and plumber. He is also the superintendent of his building, 131 Riverside Drive, at 85th Street, a sprawling brick and limestone grande dame that celebrates its 100th birthday this year. In the last decade, it has accrued many capital improvements -- a playroom, a new laundry room, a gym -- all built by Mr. Vassallo. And its residents have made their own improvements to their apartments, with Mr. Vassallo doing much of the work. 
 ''Sam is so integral to all our lives,'' said Carol Pratt, a former board member and a building resident for 12 years. ''He goes way beyond the call of duty and has so many skills. But we didn't have a super's apartment that was appropriate for a family, and we couldn't afford to buy one.''
 Mr. Vassallo, however, had been saving assiduously since he moved to New York from Malta 16 years ago. ''I always had the thought to buy an apartment,'' he said, explaining a bank account that reached a very healthy balance before the purchase of this apartment last year. ''It's not hard, you know,'' he continued, smiling at a visitor's raised eyebrows. ''I've worked at least two jobs and 80 hours a week from the beginning.''
 His first five years here, he said, he worked as a handyman from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. at a building on East 87th Street, and then as a doorman from 11 p.m. to 7 a.m. at another building, on East 32nd. Sleep was confined to the hours between 5 and 10 p.m. He lived with a friend on West 89th; in exchange for rent, he took out the garbage and performed other maintenance for that building. Two days a week, he worked as a security guard. 
 ''I was single, I didn't buy clothes or spend a lot on food,'' he said. ''I would never put down $6 for a sandwich, or eat at a restaurant. Now, of course, it's a different story.'' 
 During his first two years as super of 131 Riverside, Mr. Vassallo kept his night job. Thereafter, when tenants began asking him to paint, wire or build for them, he exchanged his night doorman job for the renovations. He met Ms. Vassallo in Malta in 1998, home on one of the rare vacations he allowed himself.
 ''In the beginning, when you first come to New York,'' Mr. Vassallo said, ''you want to earn money and go back to Malta. It changes, though, because you get used to the life.''
 Ms. Vassallo added, ''And then it's too quiet for you back home.'' 
 He and Ms. Vassallo were married in 2000 -- four residents from 131 Riverside attended their wedding in Malta -- and she moved into the small, dark one-bedroom super's apartment Mr. Vassallo had been living in since 1994. And then Evie arrived. 
 ''I proposed to the board that I would like to purchase an apartment,'' Mr. Vassallo said. ''I had an idea that this one was going to come up.''
 This one was a near wreck, owned by the estate of a woman who had lived in it for 51 years, Mr. Vassallo said. ''It was scary,'' he said. ''The doors were painted black; there were seven locks on the front door; people were afraid to come in.''
 He approached the tenant's heir, who referred him to her lawyer, who in turn declared that the apartment would be offered for sale with an open house one Sunday last September. It was a typical Manhattan scene, Mr. Vassallo said, with 20 or 25 couples thronging the apartment, all vibrating with anxiety and need. Mr. Vassallo sought advice from Lee Waldman of Stribling & Associates, a resident of 131 Riverside for 44 years and the principal broker for the building -- though Ms, Waldman did not have the listing for this apartment. 
 ''I've sold perhaps 25 apartments here, some of them three or four times over,'' Ms. Waldman said the other day. ''I tried to buy this one for Sam before it went on the market, but the owner wasn't interested. Sam asked me, 'How much do I have to pay?' and I said, 'The asking price. Otherwise you're not going to get it.''' 
 At the end of the open house, Mr. Vassallo tendered his offer, in writing, to the listing broker at the open house, and was quickly accepted. ''In 16 years of doing this, this was like a fairy tale,'' said Lori Braverman, a real estate lawyer who represented Mr. Vassallo on his purchase and was awed by the extent of his savings. ''You usually see this kind of money from investment bankers.''
 Mr. Vassallo had prepared his board package in advance and was examined, and then approved, just like any other shareholder, except that the board agreed to support his maintenance costs because they were not able to offer him an apartment -- and they served Champagne at his interview.
 ''He went through the same financial screening as any shareholder,'' said Deborah Kurz, a resident for 14 years and the co-op board president for the last four years (her term ended two weeks ago). ''We decided it was a win-win situation. Sam is a wonderful super, and he brings cohesiveness to our building. The quality of the work in his apartment is indicative of the work he's done throughout the building. It is an example of the standards he sets and meets.'' 
 Mr. Vassallo is a pretty good architect, too, reworking some of the odder spaces in his new apartment to create a rangy family home. A 17-foot-long bathroom became two; the tangle of pantry, maid's room and tiny kitchen has been unraveled to make a bedroom for Sal, an airy, open kitchen and a third bathroom. Those cherry wood cabinets were built by two Maltese brothers, Godwin and Frank Cauchi, in a tiny basement space. 
 ''He's a super friend,'' Mr. Vassallo said of Godwin Cauchi. ''We've known each other 15 years.'' 
 You wonder, what is it about the arid island between Sicily and Tunisia that makes such extraordinary craftsmen? Mr. Vassallo shrugged and twinkled a bit.
 Malta also provided the beveled glass for his six French doors (that's 90 pieces of glass). A Manhattan estimate was $5,000; a Maltese supplier came in at $1,500. Mr. Vassallo has put the remainder of his savings into this renovation -- which was completed this month -- an amount that includes materials only. All the work -- the carpentry, plumbing and wiring -- was done by Mr. Vassallo. 
 His taste is refined and luxurious, judging from the wine fridge, the second oven, the Bosch and Viking appliances, and the new parquet floor with its Harlequin border, all laid in by Mr. Vassallo. 
 The most luxurious touches, however -- the many sconces, chandeliers and pendant lamps that adorn the walls and ceilings -- are examples of Mr. Vassallo's most prescient economies, as every light fixture was salvaged, plucked from the discards of other apartments as tenants renovated. 
 ''We have very good garbage in this building,'' Mr. Vassallo said. He is a passionate steward of 131 Riverside, proudly showing off its lobby renovation, including the faux wood trompe l'oeil on the steel doors.
 ''I feel very lucky,'' he continued, pointing to his own shiny black door. ''There were originally seven locks to this door. Now I only have one, and I never lock it.''
 Mr. Vassallo has very good neighbors.

Mr. Vassallo is the building's superintendent. (Photographs by Phil Mansfield for The New York Times)(pg. 4)

HEADLINE: Responding To the Law Of 'Nimby'

BYLINE: By PAUL VITELLO

 BODY:
PERHAPS the most surprising thing about the past few stormy weeks in the life of Steve Levy, Suffolk's county executive, is that he seems surprised.
 He seems surprised by the names he has been called and perhaps even by the names he has called others. He expresses surprise at the intensive news media attention from near and far, all of it, as he sees it, because he has enforced the law.
 ''I'm frustrated at the myths that are being perpetrated,'' he said in an interview on Tuesday, more than three weeks after he touched off the storm by sending Suffolk police officers to help shut down an illegal rooming house in Farmingville where more than 60 men, most of them illegal immigrants, were living. 
 When advocates for immigrants immediately accused Mr. Levy of insensitivity and race-baiting, he exploded in anger -- first at the advocates, and then at the news media for what he considered unfair coverage. 
 ''I'm 'insensitive' because I'm enforcing the law?'' he said. ''This is what you call damned if you do and damned if you don't.''
 The immigrant problems in Suffolk County are not the county's alone, of course. The workers are part of a nationwide influx, mainly from Latin America, of people seeking the economic opportunity they cannot find at home, and sparks have flown in communities across the country where concentrations of illegal immigrants have appeared. Washington has sent mixed signals about how to handle the influx, so local officials like Mr. Levy have been left to their own devices, which are usually a limited set of political tools and traditions.
 The late-20th-century suburban landscape that produced Mr. Levy may be remembered in the future for a long list of things -- sprawl, the soccer mom, the four-car garage, the Levitt splanch -- but planning won't be on that list.
 What defines this landscape instead is the first law of suburban life, known by the acronym Nimby, for ''not in my backyard.'' It deems that all comers are free to do as they please, as long as it doesn't displease the people next door. 
 This unwritten law of the land is central to the lives of all its politicians -- the more homegrown the politician, the more deeply so -- and there are few politicians on Long Island more homegrown than Mr. Levy, who is a native of Holbrook. So when he entered the county executive's office in 2004 after 14 years as a main-street Democrat -- famous for the door-to-door campaigning that won him six terms in the County Legislature and one in the State Assembly, always from Republican districts -- he was sure to hear the howl rising long and loud from the hamlet of Farmingville.
 Residents there had complained for years about illegal immigrants gathering for day-labor shape-ups in local 7-Eleven parking lots and living, crammed 40 and 50 to a house, on streets of single-family homes. The overcrowding was sometimes so severe, neighbors said, that the men were forced to use the backyards as bathrooms.
 Mr. Levy's predecessor, Robert J. Gaffney, a Republican and former F.B.I. agent, seemed stymied by the crisscrossing mandates of federal immigration policy and local peacekeeping. But Mr. Levy has appeared to see the situation from the start as a neighborhood nuisance problem with a local solution. 
 ''There's only two ways you can go with this,'' he said. ''You enforce the law, or you don't.'' He meant the local health and building codes, but perhaps also the reason they exist, the unwritten law of Nimby.
 His first move last fall was to try to ''deputize'' county police officers as federal immigration agents. When the police union balked, he turned to lending their services to the Town of Brookhaven's building department.
 The town had its sights on what it said were 117 illegal rooming houses in Farmingville, almost all crowded with laborers who cut lawns, bus dishes and paint houses for sub-minimum wages. 
 When outraged advocates for immigrants called his tactics ''ethnic cleansing,'' he dismissed them as a ''a lunatic fringe.'' He lambasted newspaper and television coverage of the men left homeless by the rooming house raids, telling reporters at a news conference on Monday that they had missed the real story, about the ''integrity of neighborhoods,'' and sputtering in indignation at any suggestion that he was singling out Hispanic immigrants or playing to voters' prejudices. 
 ''I like Steve, but I think what's he's done is shameful,'' said Paul Tonna, a county legislator. ''And the fact that many people in Suffolk County are happy about it -- I hear his poll numbers have gone up since he did this -- is even more shameful.'' The poll results he referred to could not be confirmed.
 ''Steve Levy is very much attuned to what I call the windbreaker man,'' said David Bishop, a county legislator who sat next to Mr. Levy at legislative meetings for years. Mr. Bishop described this prototype as the ''Korean war veteran'' who happens to be conservative, Republican-leaning, independent-voting, tax-hating and law-and-order-loving.
 ''He knows exactly what that guy is thinking,'' Mr. Bishop said, ''and that's how he has been able to survive.''
 From the beginning of his career, Mr. Levy has trod a fine line among his several chosen roles as anti-establishment reformer, tax-cutting conservative, environmentalist and the windbreaker man's best friend.
 Patrick Halpin, the last Democratic county executive before Mr. Levy, sees in him a politician ''who eventually ends up in a decent place but has a tendency to appeal to people's worst instincts.''
 In his last term in the County Legislature, for instance, Mr. Levy supported an English-only bill that would have set legal limits on the county's use of Spanish. It was deeply resented in the Hispanic community and ultimately vetoed by Mr. Gaffney. But Mr. Levy's support seems to have left an indelible impression on advocates like the Rev. Allan Ramirez of the Brookville Reformed Church, who has called Mr. Levy evil.
 Mr. Levy's relations with Suffolk's Hispanic population have been soured further by the resignations of Renee L. Ortiz, Mr. Levy's chief of minority affairs, in April and 9 of the 19 members of his Hispanic Advisory Board on July 7. 
 But Mr. Levy's calculation is that sooner or later, everyone will benefit from his policies, Hispanic and non-Hispanic alike. 
 ''I analogize it to what Rudy Giuliani did when he stopped the squeegee men,'' Mr. Levy said in an interview. ''The extremists said he was trampling on rights. But now, even his harshest critics are grateful that they can walk the streets.''
 Alex Gutierrez, a high school Spanish teacher who remains on the Hispanic Advisory Board as its chairman, said he saw Mr. Levy as well intentioned. ''Those places are a disgrace,'' he said, ''and people should put the blame where it belongs, on the landlords.''
 But he also expressed sympathy for the men displaced from the rooming houses. ''These are people taking jobs that no one else wants, and the government should give them working papers so they can participate and pay their taxes,'' Mr. Gutierrez said. ''These people are here to stay.''
 What happens next to those men is a question not answered, and apparently not asked, by Mr. Levy.
 ''It may not be politically correct to say, but the goal of many of these immigrants is not to establish roots here,'' he said Tuesday, ''but only to work here and mail back as much money as possible to their family elsewhere.''
 Still, how should those men be treated while they are here, he was asked. What is the plan?
 Mr. Levy answered without a pause: ''The plan is to enforce the law.''

HEADLINE: Detroit Not Dying

 BODY:

To the Sports Editor:
 As a longtime resident of Michigan, I was disappointed in Tyler Kepner's article about Tiger Stadium (''A Former Baseball Cathedral Now Lies Neglected and Decrepit,'' July 10). With so many positive developments in this city, it is sad that an out-of-town journalist would reach so deep to come up with the proverbial ''Detroit is dying'' story.
Do area residents wish that part of town was experiencing redevelopment and growth, as many other sections of the city? Absolutely. But to imply that the vacant stadium is symbolic of Detroit's fate is not a vision shared by Detroiters or those who care about its future.

Randall Foutch
Farmington Hills, Mich.

HEADLINE: Critics and Fans Alike As Navy Chief Steps Down

BYLINE: By THOM SHANKER and ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16 

 BODY:
Adm. Vern Clark is stepping down next week as the longest-serving chief of naval operations in a half-century, having spent five years revamping the fleet and trimming Navy budgets in an unusual sacrifice to help pay the Army's bills in Iraq.
 He has increased the Navy's readiness, improved pay and benefits, accelerated the retirement of outdated ships, and submerged parochial Navy interests as a team player on the Joint Chiefs of Staff. And what thanks does he get? 
 He has been pilloried by the ship-building industry and members of Congress, and not just those representing districts with shipyards or Navy ports. Within his own branch of the service and among retired officers, it is easy to find people who wish he had fought harder for the Navy's share of the pie. 
 But he also got an unusual second term, granted by Donald H. Rumsfeld, the most hands-on defense secretary in a generation. Even more important, he has been given much leeway in organizing, training and equipping the Navy, a liberty that has been the envy of those leading the other armed services.
 When confronted by critics who count success by the numbers and believe that only size matters, whether in ships, personnel or budgets, Admiral Clark says the friction proves that the system works.
 ''The people that would criticize are again performing a specific role that they've been given to play inside the system that we have,'' Admiral Clark, 60, said in an interview looking back over his last five years. ''A congressman that represents a district where they build ships, I expect them to speak strongly in support of their region and their shipyard and the economic imperatives that go with that. And I decided that I wasn't going to lose a lot of sleep about that.''
 Admiral Clark's tour as chief of naval operations has been bracketed by terror and war. He took over in 2000, just 11 weeks before a bombing off Yemen ripped a hole in the destroyer Cole and brought terrorism's threat to the Navy. Then came the Sept. 11 attacks, which led into wars in Afghanistan and Iraq that still deeply involve his branch today.
 In the two wars, Navy aircraft flew a heavy percentage of the attack sorties, and sea-launched cruise missiles were let loose. But the Navy also adapted to new circumstances, especially in Afghanistan, a country with no coastline. Navy Seals continue to carry out Special Operations missions there, and the service's P-3 Orion, a propeller-driven aircraft designed to fly at low speed over the high seas searching for enemy submarines, has been just as useful in spotting insurgents crossing the scorching desert. 
 Admiral Clark's legacy is further complicated by orders from President Bush and Mr. Rumsfeld to transform his branch within the centralized, planned economy of the military budget.
 He played his role on the Joint Chiefs of Staff under newly defined rules, paying more than just lip service to the ''all for one, one for all'' concept designed to unite the four armed services into a more effective fighting force. He paid by squeezing his own budget.
 He answered the call for transforming the military into a leaner, deadlier and more agile force by trimming Navy personnel so he could increase pay and benefits. He made sure that only the most qualified were asked to remain by instituting a ''perform to serve'' program that winnowed re-enlistments, even as the ground component barely reached its recruitment goals. Under his watch, active-duty personnel dropped by more than 20,000 people, to 362,488 as of Friday from a high of 383,108 in 2002.
 Admiral Clark allowed the Navy to shrink to 287 ships today from 315 in 2000, and has even proposed retiring an aircraft carrier -- certainly among the crown jewels of the Navy -- to save billions of dollars.
 Senators Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, and George Allen, Republican of Virginia, are among those angered by that proposal. They are trying to block the move with legislation requiring the Navy to maintain at least a dozen carrier strike groups. 
 ''When we are at war,'' Mr. Nelson said, ''this is not a time to reduce carriers.''
 Mr. Allen added, ''Now is not the time to do anything that will weaken our strategic military capability of responding quickly and decisively to project our power.''
 At the same time, however, Admiral Clark established a system that allows the Navy to actually double the number of major warships that can be sent into battle quickly. That system, the Fleet Response Plan, compresses the lengthy maintenance cycles for carrier strike groups and redirects money to ready the fleet for war. 
 He also challenged Navy culture with a sea-swap experiment, leaving ships on duty longer than the traditional six months and rotating in fresh crews to operate them.
 Beyond these visible efforts, Admiral Clark worked on issues behind closed doors. He broke the code of how to speak with Mr. Rumsfeld, drawing on experience as commander of the Atlantic Fleet and director of the military's Joint Staff. He also holds an M.B.A., which helped him speak the bottom-line language the defense secretary understands. Pentagon insiders say that only Gen. Richard B. Myers, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs, and Gen. Peter Pace, the vice chairman, have a better line of communication with Mr. Rumsfeld.
 Ask Admiral Clark how he did it, and he gives as an example ''the pucks,'' a packet full of flat circles and a book of classified computer rankings for every potential Navy leader. The system allowed him and Mr. Rumsfeld to shift piles around a desk to plan assignments, education, training and promotions.
 ''One of the reasons this has worked with Rumsfeld is because of tools like this,'' Admiral Clark said. ''In this book is the ranking of all officers in a competitive category, done on a computer-based decision software, that none of our people saw. I show this to Don Rumsfeld, and he knows that this isn't Vern pushing his cousin. This is the collective wisdom and judgment of the senior leadership team of the United States Navy.''
 Admiral Clark laughed when service on the Joint Chiefs of Staff was compared to a real-world, high-stakes version of the ''prisoner's dilemma,'' the theoretical exercise developed by economists and nuclear strategists. The game lays out a situation in which members of a gang are arrested together but interrogated separately, and analyzes whether they will stick together for the benefit of all or cut private deals for their own benefit.
 Even within his own branch, Admiral Clark ended traditional equities that automatically divided money among submarines, surface ships and naval aircraft.
 ''I told Don Rumsfeld in front of the chiefs that day that I was putting everything on the table that the United States Navy owned, and that if we didn't need it that the taxpayers shouldn't have to buy it, and they shouldn't have to spend their money for stuff that was all about a bunch of us playing an ego game,'' Admiral Clark said. ''I just refuse to be part of that. And if anybody else decided they wanted to play like that, let them play like that, but I'm not accountable for them. I'm accountable for me.''
 The question is how this emphasis on personnel and readiness will be managed by Admiral Clark's successors, beginning with the new chief of naval operations, Adm. Michael G. Mullen, who is charged with building a Navy for 2020 and beyond. To that question, Admiral Clark holds the course he has set since 2000.
 ''Where would we be today if five years ago I made shipbuilding my No.1 priority? Where would we be?'' Admiral Clark said. ''We wouldn't have been ready.
 ''When we got ready to go do Iraq in the December meeting of '02, Dick Myers turns to me and he says, 'Vern, can I have four carriers?''' Admiral Clark continued. ''And one of the thrills of my life was, I said, 'Yeah, Dick, you can have eight if you want.'''

HEADLINE: Housing Revival in Bleak Part of Newark

BYLINE: By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
FOUR years ago this month, two spiffy new two-family homes opened as models for new construction in a seriously deteriorated Newark neighborhood off Route 78 near Newark Liberty International Airport.
 The two brick-front colonials, each with a three-bedroom, two-bath owner's unit on the second floor and a slightly less roomy tenant's apartment on the first floor, signaled the start of a grand redevelopment plan. It aims eventually to provide 1,500 new homes in Newark -- doubling the number of owner-occupied dwellings that existed in the whole city in the year 2000.
''People were wildly interested from the start,'' said Ken Baris, president of Jordan Baris Realty, which is marketing the homes at Southwyck Estates, the 240-unit first phase of development under the plan. ''We signed 10 contracts that first week, and the developers -- Summit Real Estate -- took the ball and ran as fast as possible.'' 
 Now, there are 100 two-family houses up -- whole blocks of them in some places; in others, new buildings interspersed with old. And demand for the homes remains strong. The model at Southwyck Estates that sold for $210,000 when the project started is now listed for $400,000.
 The existing two- to four-family structures that dot the area fanning out from the corner of Hillside Avenue and Runyon Street in Newark's South Ward have not gotten any younger, Mr. Baris noted. ''Still, they seem to look a little more upright, if only by association,'' he laughed.
 ''The neighborhood, which was really one of the most challenged in the city of Newark, is now really a place anybody can feel comfortable walking around in,'' Mr. Baris added.
 And the impact seems to be even more widespread than that. The average sale price for single-family homes in Newark has grown significantly, according to the Garden State Multiple Listing Service figures analyzed by Jordan Baris, a firm that has dominated the Newark residential market for the last half-century. The firm was founded in 1952 by Ken Baris's father, who remains its chief executive.
 ''I think it's clear that the new construction and creation of a stable multifamily neighborhood are helping to increase the overall property values of Newark,'' the younger Mr. Baris said. 
 The average sale price of a single-family home in the first quarter of this year soared 32 percent over the average price a year earlier, rising to $201,050 from $151,909, according to his analysis. 
 While the final numbers for the second quarter of 2005 are not yet available, enough figures are in to know that sale prices averaged 30 percent more than in 2004, indicating the trend has staying power, Mr. Baris said.
 The average time on the market increased from 76 in the first quarter to 88 days in the second quarter, he said, adding that this was not a surprising development in light of slightly higher mortgage interest rates.
 The percentage increase in average sale price for Newark was sharply higher than that for all of Essex County, where Newark is the county seat. The average price in Essex County rose 18 percent, to $459,602.
 In Union and Morris Counties, where Jordan Baris also maintains offices and sells homes, the average prices were up 15 and 16 percent, respectively, this year over last, Mr. Baris said, adding that Newark does not provide a majority of his company's sales. 
 ''The volume of sales in Newark is on the rise, though,'' he said. ''In the first three months of this year, there were 72 sales -- up 24 percent over the same period the year before.'' In the second quarter, the number of sales was also up more than 20 percent, he said.
 ''Affordability'' is probably the main reason that prices in Newark rose faster than values in the surrounding counties, Mr. Baris said. 
 ''Some buyers are worried about today's high prices and a possible decline in high-end values,'' he said. ''Moderately priced homes are increasingly seen as a safer, less-volatile investment.
 ''I think home prices in Newark increased the most because owner-occupants and investors have decided that's where the room for growth in value is,'' Mr. Baris continued. ''High-end prices are more sensitive to factors such as Wall Street bonuses and stock market performance. The more affordable a price is, the less you are tied to economic factors.''
 At Southwyck Estates, most of the homes are sold before they are built. The buyers are prequalified and may receive counseling on the basics of home ownership and being a landlord. Part of the appeal of a two-family home, of course, has traditionally been that a stable rent income helps pay the mortgage. 
 But with prices rising so fast at Southwyck, Mr. Baris said, he is beginning to see buyers who are weighing the options. ''Some people ask themselves: should we buy a new two-family for $400,000, or a larger house, built in 1940, with no tenant, probably no garage, maybe an old kitchen for $125,000 less?''
 Some other older neighborhoods are experiencing significant increases in average sale price too, he said.
 He mentioned the Vailsburg and Ivy Hill neighborhoods, which run along the Newark border with Maplewood and South Orange. ''You can drive into Ivy Hill, and you won't know you've left South Orange,'' Mr. Baris asserted. ''The prices there have gone way up, but they're still much lower than South Orange, so it has become very attractive.''
 In the Forest Hill neighborhood, replete with huge Victorians and old stone manors, the asking prices have also skyrocketed in the last few years, Mr. Baris said.
 ''You've gone from a situation where you might have sold a house for $225,000 three or four years ago, and the owner would give you a big hug at the closing, to one where asking prices are hitting $600,000,'' he said. ''I saw one on the market recently for $699,000.''
 Jordan Baris harks back 20 years, to a time when the city had so much abandoned and vacant property fall into its hands that it had to hire his company just to make a simple inventory. His 41-year-old son recalls when property owners were so eager to get rid of their houses and apartment buildings that hundreds of them actually paid a $150 fee to the city to take them.
 ''Given all this, Newark is becoming an incredible success story,'' the younger Mr. Baris said. ''The numbers are really up. You can't even argue with it.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: AN INCREASINGLY COMFORTABLE AREA -- Some of the 100 two-family homes that have been built in the first phase of development at Southwyck Estates in Newark's South Ward. (Photo by Timothy Ivy for The New York Times)

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 7; Column 2; Book Review Desk; POETRY CHRONICLE; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 2462 words

BYLINE: By Joel Brouwer and Joshua Clover. 
Joel Brouwer is the author of two books of poems, ''Exactly What Happened'' and ''Centuries.'' He teaches at the University of Alabama. Joshua Clover's most recent book is ''The Matrix''; his next collection of poems, ''The Totality for Kids,'' will be published at the end of the year.

 BODY:
 WHILE WE'VE STILL GOT FEET: New Poems. By David Budbill. (Copper Canyon, paper, $15.) Budbill belongs to the tradition in American letters inaugurated by Thoreau and continuing today in manifestations both benign (Wendell Berry) and malignant (Ted Kaczynski), wherein the writer abandons the cacophony of human society for a little paradise in the woods, but instead of quietly living out his days in smog-free solitude insists on coming to town (or writing an essay, or mailing a bomb) every few months to remind us of what a benighted existence we're living. Budbill's Walden, in Vermont, sounds like an enchanting place, with a ''lovely garden / sleeping quietly now under the snow,'' ''an evening grosbeak / perched on the topmost branch of the / fifty-foot-high white pine tree / here on the edge of the dooryard'' and days filled with reverie. Still, it seems presumptuous for Budbill to assume we'd want to crash his hermitage: ''So much silence / is frightening. Better not come here if you / don't want to fall in upon yourself. Better yet, / better not come here at all.'' Such moments are few, though. Budbill's frank self-awareness keeps him from sounding smug for long; he's quick to include himself among the benighted. When Budbill's on his mountain, he longs for the city, and vice versa. Fame, wealth and sex are false gods, he insists, but he hastens to add that he still, at times, craves all three. These are not new ideas -- a list of references in the book shows how strongly he's been influenced by the classical Chinese poets -- but they find fresh expression here, thanks to Budbill's good humor and gusto. Joel Brouwer
 TANTALUS IN LOVE. By Alan Shapiro. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.) ''All the new thinking is about loss,'' begins Robert Hass's ''Meditation at Lagunitas,'' one of the bellwether poems of our climate. ''In this it resembles all the old thinking.'' Isn't it pretty to think so? Poetry of loss these days, however painful or redemptive, seems to take cold comfort in shutting out complexity, and the possibility there's something new under the sun. Shapiro is an eloquent example. In ''Tantalus in Love,'' he thinks incessantly of loss. A marriage fails, loved ones die, the clock steams pitilessly along; meanwhile, the quatrains run on time. Those who've encountered the author's seven previous collections will recognize the territory. Shapiro handles these universal subjects with acuity; he cuts his eyes at discreet domestic details and they cut back. The husband's lacerated rhapsodizing over his distant wife's foot-of-the-bed yoga practice, in the poem ''Anger,'' is to die for; you can't decide whom to like less, and that's what keeps the poem interesting. Such tightly framed tales of domesticity offer a sense of control parallel to Shapiro's formal facility, reducing and clarifying the poem's field of action in defense against an abysmal multiplicity of things. Who wouldn't, these days, want to imagine that the bedroom, even the unhappy one, is the true arena of our lives? Such strategic exclusions can go too far. ''Didn't someone say somewhere,'' he asks at the end of ''Anger,'' ''if you shot an arrow it would never / reach its target, since the distance could / be halved, and halved, and halved, ad infinitum?'' Yes, someone did: Zeno, as it happens. We all know this, Shapiro included; why pretend otherwise? An austerity program of the sensibilities is one thing; playing dumb amid classical philosophical references is quite another. Joshua Clover
 THE LAST TIME I SAW AMELIA EARHART: Poems. By Gabrielle Calvocoressi. (Persea, paper, $13.95.) Calvocoressi brings keen and sympathetic attention to the local disasters the larger world has often overlooked, from a 1944 circus fire to a small town poisoned by its factory to even less visible dramas of personal longing and loss. The political edge in a poem like ''The Death of Towns,'' which describes an industrial town of ''huddled and wheezing'' workers and a river so poisoned the fish ''wore their organs / on the outside,'' recalls the work of Muriel Rukeyser, but Eavan Boland is a more pervasive influence here; like her, Calvocoressi is more interested in archetypal history than in documentary particulars. In the book's long title poem, a succession of speakers project their own yearnings onto Earhart, gradually turning her into a metaphor for the American dream of escape. When a high school teacher who took her class to see Earhart fly says of one student, ''Camille's father lost an arm / to the canning factory. / She left us to take his place,'' the antecedent for ''she'' remains ambiguous. Just as the daughter left school for the cannery, Earhart left earth to provide us all with a dream of transcendence. Calvocoressi's ability to shape and control complex long poems is remarkable, but at times she keeps her subjects at arm's length. ''From the Adult Drive-In'' is the best of the four long poems that make up the bulk of this collection, largely because its narrator, an adolescent who watches the forbidden films from her hiding place in ''the darkening pines,'' doesn't just observe but implicates herself: ''What was it they wanted that I wanted too?'' J.B.
 LETTERED CREATURES: Light Verse. By Brad Leithauser. Illustrated by Mark Leithauser. (Godine, $19.95.) A chaotic world made manageable (and memorable) via ordering of parts is the ''New Formalist'' dream; it has no more formidable dreamer than Brad Leithauser. MacArthur grantee and author of carefully wrought poems including a verse novel, Leithauser has made a book ideally suited to his talents. ''Lettered Creatures'' is both abecedary and bestiary, from ''Anteater'' to ''Zedonk'' (my dictionary offers the felicitous alternative ''zonkey''). It's packed with charming rhymes (''reader'' / ''Bottom Feeder,'' ''joey'' / ''vertigo-y'') and gallivanting lexicon, justified in ''Octopi'': ''Only the outsize net / Of an odd, overwrought vocabulary / Offers the slightest possibility / Of capturing our inky souls.'' Moments later he drops the word ''obnubilating''; one can be certain he means it. The book is illustrated by his brother, Mark, whose work is said to resemble Audubon's and Tenniel's. Maybe so; it has an affinity also to the animations in Tim Burton's movies, the sort of menacing comic melancholy that really spruces up a camel. This strikes the right tone for reputedly ''light verse,'' pushing the book into the category kids' stuff for adults. In that, the Leithausers' rhyme syndicate is the complement of Tenniel and his collaborator Lewis Carroll, whose Alice put adult stuff on offer for kids. J.C.
 PYX. By Corinne Lee. (Penguin, paper, $18.) A pyx is a box used to store the bread-become-flesh of the Eucharist. Lee's book functions similarly, as a container for the daily bread of life experiences -- marriage and motherhood, in particular -- transubstantiated into poetry. The means of transformation are naturally not divine, but lingual. Packed with extravagant sounds and elaborate vocabularies, ''Pyx'' is a great joy to read aloud. Picking lines almost at random I find ''fall's leaf smoke slips in, / a vellum gravy / on our tongues,'' children returning from play ''shellacked with muck'' and ''sacristies hold caches / of crutches flung aside / like chopsticks.'' Such surfeits of sound can sometimes feel as campy as kazoo music, and Lee's determination to never, ever select the expected word can lead to awkwardness and obscurity. There's no reason to say ''the vox populi queried,'' when ''the people asked'' would do, and the book is rife with lines that probably hold fairly straightforward significance but are too heavily cloaked in metaphor to be understood. ''Slurry'' begins, ''I'll not be covert / and, thus, your capital. Take your pill: Today / is my cedar / disposition,'' which I might be able to make sense of, were I not in such a tamarack mood myself. More often than not, though, Lee is able to focus and control her considerable gifts, and the results can be glorious, as when she describes a baby as ''a fontanel, / cooing and crested / with auburn down, filling / my breasts' cleft. Day-old colostrum / like nougat / on her slightly older chin. Both pinnacle and vortex, / she is. Will always be.'' J.B.
 LEDGER. By Susan Wheeler. (University of Iowa, paper, $14.) Wheeler's poetry doesn't shy from difficulty, complexity or confusion. Her lyrical mode is often one of delight: ''Tyvek Bruce Willis Buffalo Bertelsman,'' she offers in her new book, and ''Nike Iowa Snapple Foucault.'' Nonsense syllables with juicy mouthfeel, or life in the forest of brand names and word games? Either way, Wheeler holds a door open for the jumble of history: Dutch painting and British theology room with old riddles and New York Times articles. If ''Ledger'' brings an order to the world's welter, it's that it speaks often of debt and admits often of guilt. Economics and emotion face each other across a charged field; stuff gathers in the middle, glittery as a sack of diamonds. The risk is that it's just data, Frank O'Hara's ''I do this, I do that'' poem with the ''I'' sidelined, and seeing in place of doing. It would still then be a book of our times, fascinated as these poems are by, in one critic's words, ''mobility, elusiveness, disembodiment, pure visibility and confinement to the world of signs.'' That sounds abstract; at the drop of a hat, Wheeler gets down to brass tacks. Or gold tacks, perhaps. The knockout final poem, ''The Debtor in the Convex Mirror'' (the title nodding to John Ashbery), tracks that trivial thing abounding with metaphysical subtleties and theological niceties, the gold coin. This ''fragment of the debt'' leads us from 16th-century Antwerp to today, ending in Brooklyn with the question of what we owe each other left aching and unresolved -- much less the question of how we'll pay, when saddled with ''Zero / and then sum.'' J.C.
 CRUSH. By Richard Siken. (Yale University, cloth, $26; paper, $14.95.) Siken's title is meant to suggest both that fizzy eighth-grade feeling and the anaconda that tightens in our guts when love fails, but above all the choice between rock and hard place all lovers must make: pursue and risk rejection, or withdraw and risk loneliness. Siken's solution to this quandary is implicit in the title of the book's first poem, ''Scheherazade.'' If he can keep the narrative of his amorous obsession in constant motion, he can defer romantic failure forever. Of course, he'll reach no happy ending. But Siken's not much interested in endings or beginnings; his territory is the passionate apex of an affair, where ripeness first tips toward rot. As Siken teeters on that summit, hysteria creeps into his lines, especially in the virtuosic ''Saying Your Names,'' where the poet struggles to hold on to his lover (referred to in other poems as Henry) by enmeshing him in a web of alternative names: ''Your name like two X's like punched-in eyes, / like a drunk cartoon passed out in the gutter, / your name with two X's to mark the spots, / to hold the place, to keep the treasure from / becoming ever lost.'' An entire book at this pace would become exhausting, but Siken deftly balances such headlong passages with more stately, deliberate lines: ''Every morning the same big / and little words all spelling out desire, all spelling out / You will be alone always and then you will die.'' Best of all are the poems where Siken's passion and eloquence collide and fuse: ''This is where the evening / splits in half, Henry, love or death. Grab an end, pull hard, / and make a wish.'' J.B.
 THIS CONNECTION OF EVERYONE WITH LUNGS: Poems. By Juliana Spahr. (University of California, cloth, $45; paper, $16.95.) Both of the extended pieces that constitute Spahr's new book -- ''Poem Written After September 11, 2001'' and ''Poem Written From November 30, 2002, to March 27, 2003'' -- start with the cellular, the intimate, and reach after the whole shebang. It's political poetry the way it's love poetry; how can it not be, when you go for the everything? The longer, latter portion tracks the approach to the war in Iraq, in fact and in public speech, via some data fountain like Google News. But this means we're soaking in it: cloned sheep, global warming, Ben and J.Lo (Those were the days!). It's a poetics of superinformation: a world where everything is connected, not only by virtue of the Rube Goldberg machine called history, but by the insistent flatness of data, the screen where all that appears, appears equivalent. Spahr is a desolate tenant of this information. She dwells inside the tightening web of connection that links her pointedly plural ''beloveds'' and ''yous'' in their lush corner of Hawaii, to the unceasing cataract of facts, the nausea and euphoria of the new sublime: ''In bed, when I stroke the down on yours cheeks, I stroke also the carrier battle group ships, the guided missile cruisers.'' It's not a comfortable or even manageable condition. The hard-won verdict that ends the book, ''all of us / with all of that,'' is ambivalent, emotionally difficult, as it must be. The book seems, finally, like poetry from the 21st century, poised between trying to vault from the flatness of this new world and trying to inhabit it fully. J.C.
 THE ECLIPSES: Poems. By David Woo. (BOA Editions, paper, $14.95.) Woo's subject is the challenges of caring for his aging parents, and of doing so with a potent combination of deep compassion and cleareyed scrutiny. One poem, ''My Mother's Hands,'' begins, ''Now that she's ashamed of their ancient burls and gibbous knobs -- / 'Don't be ashamed!' I cry -- / I find myself staring at the raw matter of their decay, / nails crumbling to the opalescent grit / of their lunulae, liver spots speckling the dorsal vein / with its throbbing blue limbs, as if the leopard, / symbol of lust in Dante, lay panting, enfeebled, / in the dark wood.'' The honesty here is remarkable: Woo is obviously sympathetic, but he makes no effort to conceal his fascination with his mother's decline. This graceful book succeeds least when the poems are too well behaved; it's disappointing to see a leaf described as ''enflamed with autumn'' or a bobcat ''the size of my neighbor's small collie,'' when we know the poet is capable of fresher ideas. The strongest poems are marked by stern elegance and the faintest strain of anxiety. Where other writers might rage against the dying of the light, he offers subtle internal rhyme and delicate metaphor: ''Today the patches of sunlit mist that flow in / through the foothills and obscure the filigree / on a row of Queen Annes are occlusions / from my mother's CT-scan: that steel-blue blur / on blur of cortex and wine-dark hemorrhage.'' J.B.

SECTION: Section BU; Column 1; SundayBusiness; PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; Pg. 6

HEADLINE: For Now, the Grass Is Still Greener in Foreign Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
AS the stock market makes its second attempt this year to break out of the doldrums, investors who have stuck with American equities may be feeling a little better. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had its highest close in more than four years on Friday, while the Dow Jones industrial average is now just 360 points from a return to 11,000. 
 But just a quick glance at the performance of stock markets worldwide will make these investors painfully aware that their counterparts abroad are doing much, much better. Although the United States economy is outperforming that of a good portion of the rest of the world, the stock market isn't. 
 ''We are talking about the global economy slowing down, but their stock markets are going up,'' said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis.
 What may make American investors feel even worse is that they have been denied most of the good performance in international markets because of the sudden rally in the dollar -- except against a few emerging-market currencies like those of Mexico and Brazil.
 The dollar is not likely to weaken much very soon, said Paresh Upadhyaya, a portfolio manager at Putnam Investments. He said his quantitative guideposts remained positive across the board for the dollar.
 But while global investors still seem to favor stocks outside the United States, the trend could be shifting. And that would be good for American investors who decided to stay home. 
 The S.&P. 500 is now up 1.3 percent for the year, but the FTSE 100 index in Britain is up 8.7 percent, in pounds. It reached a 38-month high last Thursday, just five trading days after the terrorist bombings in London. (In dollar terms, that gain becomes a loss of 0.6 percent.)
 Other foreign markets are also doing well. While the Dow is still down 1.3 percent for the year, the S.&P. ASX 200 index in Australia is up 6 percent in Australian dollars (1.4 percent in American dollars). Even the Nikkei 225 is up 2.4 percent, in Japanese yen, though it is down 6.5 percent in dollars.
 Emerging markets, measured by the Morgan Stanley Capital International index, were up 9.9 percent through Thursday, in their local currencies. In dollars, the increase is cut only to 8.4 percent, because of the fall of the dollar against the Mexican peso and the Brazilian real.
 One reason for the better performance of stocks outside the United States is global investors' continuing appetite for the higher returns in emerging stock markets -- and their feeling that other developed markets can offer better performance than those in the United States. 
 ''People remain confident about the global economy and they want riskier assets'' that offer better returns, said David Bowers, the London-based chief global investment strategist for Merrill Lynch.
 ''Investors know no fear,'' he added, ''and if you want risk, you get more risk outside the United States than in the United States.''
 Mr. Bowers follows the predilections of big global institutional investors through Merrill Lynch's monthly survey of fund managers, which covers about 300 institutional investors who together manage about $1 trillion.
 In June, the survey showed that 49 percent of those money managers were underweight in United States stocks. This means that the managers have diverged from their global benchmark index by owning a lower percentage of Wall Street than the index does. Twenty-one percent were overweight in American stocks, for a significant net underweighting of 28 percent. 
 Mr. Bowers says investors tend to favor markets outside the United States when the global economy is healthy and when it appears that prices and inflation are rising.
 The ability to raise prices with increasing inflation makes the earnings potential of economically sensitive stocks, which do well in periods of growth, even more attractive. There are more such stocks and companies outside the United States, Mr. Bowers said.
 But if global growth is slowing and inflation is under control, pricing power is reduced and economically sensitive stocks become less attractive. And that may be happening now, he said, noting the very sharp drop in May and June in the prices-paid index of the Institute for Supply Management and the relatively low level of longer-term interest rates.
 ''If you believe that inflation is a problem, you stay with international stocks and avoid the United States,'' he said. ''If you believe inflation is a head fake, and that earnings are becoming a scarce commodity, then you want to be in the United States.'' That is because, in tougher times, the American market has proved to be a better haven.
 MR. BOWERS warned that money managers could now be shifting their sights back to the United States as inflation worries have subsided. The 28 percent net underweighting of American stocks in the June survey, while significant, was down from 32 percent in May and 43 percent in April.
 If this shift continues, the United States market may have the help it needs to put its stocks back on an upward trend.
